content.title: Keep track of support requests and bugs by tagging conversations
content.description: Identify and tag the most important messages, topics and trends in your feedback.
sections: Your customer support team will deal with a range of message types - from bugs, to product feedback, to complaints, to feature requests. A good support team not only resolves each customer problem, but they'll go one step further and tag each message. Over time, you'll then gather a great store of valuable information about everything your customers are telling you - and it will all be easily searchable later.

Your engineers will want to hear about the impact of their bugs for example, and your product team will want to know exactly where your customers are getting lost and confused. By tagging your messages and sharing your findings, you can make sure the right feedback is available to the right people in your company.
To tag a conversation, simply go to the message you want to tag in a conversation and click on the ellipsis icon (the three dots).
A quick action menu should appear, and from there click Tag message.
Here you can search for tags you have already created or you can add a new one. üöÄ
Apply tags in the Intercom conversations app on iOS & Android
To tag conversations on the go, follow these steps:
Long tap (press and hold) on a conversation part.Select "Tag this reply".Search and choose from your existing tags, or tap "Create new tag..."Type the name of your new tag.Tap "Save".Tap "Done"
To remove a tag, tap the "X" on the tag and select "Remove".

Long tap (press and hold) on a conversation part.Select "Tag this reply".Search and choose from your existing tags, or tap "Create new tag..."Type the name of your new tag.Tap "Enter" on your keyboard.Tap "Done"
To remove a tag, tap the "X" on the tag and select "Remove".
Identify topics and trends in your feedback

When you and your team are consistently tagging over time, you'll amass valuable data that can inform how your product evolves. Tagging conversations with general tags like "Bug" or "Feature Request" lets you search for these things later and see all conversations about that topic.

But you should also be more specific and use tags to track conversations about a particular bug or feature like "A/B Testing Bug" or "Events Feedback". Over time, you'll start to see which requests are most common, or which bugs impact the most users. This kind of information will help your team prioritize bug fixes and decide what new features to build next.
Below, we share just a few ways we categorize and tag our feedback at Intercom:

Even the best product teams ship bugs. When your users spot those bugs and report them, you need to let the relevant people know. To relay this to your team clearly and efficiently, tag it as ‚Äòbug' and leave a comment if necessary. Be sure to thank your customer for taking the time to report the issue, and if you really want to delight them, follow up and let  them know when it's fixed.

You and your team know your product better than anyone, right? But new users coming to it with fresh eyes and zero context are going to have a different perspective on it. That's why customers will often ask what a feature means or how to use it. Those conversations generally begin something like this: ‚ÄúWhat does X mean?‚Äù, ‚ÄúI don't understand why‚Ä¶‚Äù or ‚ÄúIt doesn't make sense to me that‚Ä¶‚Äù. This kind of feedback often shines a light on the product team's blindspots and can help you improve your features.

Your customers will request or ask about features that already exist in your product. These conversations highlight areas where you need to better communicate what your product can do. If you have an excellent events calendar in your product, but customers keep asking if it's possible to record events, then you don't have a product problem - you have an awareness problem. As well as your product team, your marketing or product education teams might want to know about this awareness issue. Tag it for them all.

Customers will often want your product to do more than it currently does. Take advantage of the fact that they are telling you exactly what they want. It's important to let them know the product team will see their request, and to try and understand why they're asking for that feature.

Pro Tip: Each quarter our research team generates a Customer Voice Report where they list the top 10 feature requests from our customers. This helps inform our product roadmap for the following quarter. Once you've been tagging your messages for long enough, creating this report is made far easier.

By tagging any feedback from churning customers you'll be able to prevent it from happening later by taking action earlier in the cycle. If a customer is leaving because her own business is failing, that's one thing. But if several customers are cancelling because of the recent feature ‚Äúimprovements‚Äù you made, then you've got an opportunity to directly address future churn. For example, you could send these folk a message asking what specifically they didn't like about the feature and use this feedback to improve it.

If your site or app is down or unavailable you want to know how wide the impact on your customer base has been. Tagging these communications gives our infrastructure team a sense of how performance issues are impacting customers.

This should be relatively easy and obvious to spot, but tag it so the relevant team or teams get the feedback. For example, it's useful for a designer to know that the feature they've built is doing well and that customers are getting value from it. It's also useful to have positive customer quotes that can be used in marketing materials. Just as important, remember to thank the user for sending it in.
Keep your tags up to date as your needs change
Read how to edit, archive or delete tags in this article.

Now that you're tagging your conversations, you can get an overview of any trends with the Conversation tags report. You'll gain insight into where your customers are confused, the features they request the most, how they're impacted by bugs or outages, and much more. The report can also be exported so it's easy to share.
Next, you can get insights on how your team is performing in the team inbox.

content.author:
Written by  Matthew Pelyhes
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Share articles to answer questions faster
content.description: Add articles to conversations to quickly resolve your customers' questions
sections: The Articles add-on is even more powerful if you have Inbox. You and your team can add articles to conversations to answer your customers' questions faster.
Quickly find and send articles to answer questions
When a customer asks a question, their message will arrive in your inbox, where you can add an article directly to the conversation to resolve their query quicker.
Use the shortcut Command-Shift-H, or click ‚ÄúInsert an article‚Äù in the shortcuts menu, then select the article you want to add:
If you support multiple languages in your Help Center, select which version of the article you'd like to send:
Then, go ahead and add it:
Your article will be inserted into the conversation, where you can add additional context to your message before sending it:
When you send your article, your customer will see a preview of it where they can scan the title and description, before reading it:
Once they click the preview, it expands to show the full article in the Messenger, so they can read it in context:
Note: Your customers can react to articles directly from the Messenger so you can gather rich feedback.
If you've translated the article into multiple languages, your customers can choose to read it in their preferred language:
Note: Supporting multiple languages in your Help Center is only available on certain Intercom plans. See our plans and pricing here.
You can add articles to your macros, to offer comprehensive responses to frequent questions. When creating or editing a macro, just click the insert article icon:
Get article feedback to improve your content

Operator's article feedback task bot allows you to go beyond answering your customer's question. Now that you've got feedback on your articles, you can also improve them based on customer data. This should reduce the number of questions your customers start from your articles, saving your support team even more time üòÑ
Learn how Operator automatically suggests relevant articles to users in the Messenger.

content.author:
Written by  Beth
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Customize the next-gen Inbox with apps
content.description: Get the context you need so you can support your customers faster.
sections: Context is key to providing the best possible customer experience. You can customize your conversation details to show the exact information you need, and perform actions directly in external tools without needing to leave the conversation.
By default, you'll see the standard list of conversation details to the right of your conversation:
You can customize and rearrange the order of these details, as well as add apps to see details and take actions in other tools.

Every teammate in your Intercom workspace can choose their own unique combination of apps and information to display here, so your support team can easily troubleshoot issues or report bugs, and your sales team can set up demos or start trials for new customers.
How do I customize the conversation details?

Let's say you're on the support team and a customer reports a bug in your app. It's helpful to see the actions they've taken before seeing the issue so you'll want to bring ‚ÄòRecent events' to the top. Just click ‚ÄòEdit Apps':
Then, select the pin icon to the right of ‚ÄòRecent events' to add it:
Next select the icon to the left to drag it to the top:
Pro tip: There are many built in options you can use to make your inbox more powerful and efficient:

Quick links ‚Äî Create dynamic links to other products or internal tools with user or company attributes. E.g. yourbillingsystem.com?user_id={user_id}.Recent events ‚Äî See the actions your customers have taken in your product. Total events ‚Äî Count the total number of times your customers have taken certain actions.User/Company notes ‚Äî Check notes you or your teammates have added, like: ‚ÄúDanny loves GIFs in conversations‚Äù.User/Company tags ‚Äî So you can easily apply tags like: ‚ÄúPotential_beta_candidate‚Äù.
Choosing which attributes and events are visible
With User details, Company details, and Total events you can also specify exactly which attributes and events you want to see. Just click ‚ÄòSee All' below the list:
Then, use the ‚Äòpin' icon to toggle visibility on and off, and click the back arrow at the top when you're finished:

Efficiency is important when you're supporting a high volume of customers. Removing unnecessary information is a good way to tidy up your inbox so you can focus on what's important to you and your customers.
To hide apps and information you don't need, click ‚ÄòEdit Apps', then, select the ‚Äòpin' icon on any that you would like to hide:
Note: Any changes you make to your conversation details will only apply to your view of the inbox - it won't affect your teammates's inboxes.
To make the most of your inbox, you should add apps to connect to other tools you use.
For a list of all apps that you can add in the conversation details, go to the App Store and select ‚ÄòWorks with Inbox':
Next, select the apps you'd like to use and follow the simple steps to install them.
Here are some of the apps you can install to accelerate your workflows in the inbox:

Salesforce - Create leads, and view their deals.Stripe - Upgrade your customers' subscriptions as you chat.Trello - Track feature requests, bugs and issues.Zendesk - Forward Intercom conversations to Zendesk.StatusPage - See live updates on your product's status.Shopify - Check a customer's order status as you chat.MailChimp - Subscribe users to your mailing list.
For apps built by our partners, you can find a link to their documentation in the app details view:
After you install a new app, you can click ‚ÄòEdit apps' in the inbox to add it to your conversation details:
When you install a new app, your teammates will get a notification in the inbox to let them know they can add it to their conversation details too:
Teammates with Inbox access will also receive an email linking them to the app so they can find out more:
Note: You can opt out of these notifications from your notification settings page:

Create new Salesforce leads from Intercom, and view Salesforce data in your inbox with the Salesforce app.Customize your inbox with dynamic links to other tools you use. You can also build your own custom apps for use in the inbox on Intercom's developer platform. ‚Äî These apps can also appear in Messenger, and be sent in Messages or by Operator.

content.title: Can I link to a specific reply in a conversation?
content.description: Share a user's reply with teammates by copying a link.
sections: Can I link to a specific reply in a conversation?
Yes, it's easy to share a specific reply in a conversation with a teammate. Just hover over the reply and click on the three dots:
Then, click 'Copy link to selected conversation part'':
This link will copy to your clipboard. Now, when you share the link with a teammate, it will bring them straight to that specific reply in a conversation.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: What's changed in the next-gen Inbox?
content.description: Find a detailed list of the changes and additional features in the all-new Inbox.
sections: With the all-new inbox, your team can zero in on just the context they need ‚Äì right when they need it ‚Äì to have personalized, effective conversations. Faster performance and a keyboard first approach makes every action immediate, so your team can get more done in the same amount of time. And your individual teammates can work exactly how they want ‚Äì whether that means in a different language, in dark mode, or with different visual layouts.
We'll go through each of the changes in more detail below.

The Inbox has a fresh look and feel. It's easy to learn and even quicker to use with improved performance. Each teammate can zoom in on the most important content at any given time. For example, inbox sidebars can be shown or hidden for a more focused conversation.

Everything in the Inbox is fully controllable with your keyboard through a new feature called Command-K (use Control-K on Windows). This simple, easy to remember and fail safe keyboard shortcut, gives you access to any action, piece of content, or place within the Inbox in a few seconds. Find out how to use Command-K effectively here.

Teammates will be presented with common greetings they have used to reply to conversations in the past. This smart reply will be suggested in the background of the composer (grayed out) when they first respond to a conversation.

A teammate can choose to use this smart reply by pressing the Tab key and the message will appear as regular text for them to finish composing, edit, or send.  Or, if they don't find it useful, they can simply ignore it and continue typing their own reply.

Note: Each teammate's suggested smart reply will be different as it's based on their own individual reply they use most commonly in the Inbox. The smart reply will also change if the teammate begins using a different reply more frequently.

All buttons to insert content into a reply (e.g. macros, emojis, gifs, articles, attachments, images, etc.) have been replaced with the ‚ö°Ô∏è button or keyboard shortcut Command-K (Control-K on Windows) for a cleaner composing experience.
Here's an example of how inserting a macro looks using Command-K:
You can find the ‚ÄúSend and close‚Äù and ‚ÄúSend and snooze‚Äù options in this overflow menu:
Conversation events are hidden by default, but can be made visible when you want to check them.

Teammate presence shows when someone else is viewing the conversation. You can identify them by their name and avatar at the top, so you don't need to worry about conversations that are already being looked into by another teammate.
There are some key changes to the conversation list:
Unread messages are bolded.Company name is not shown.SLAs can be seen more clearly:Red: Overdue.Orange: Less than 5 minutes left on the timer.Gray: More than 5 minutes left on the timer.
Add multiple participants by clicking into the composer and adding or removing names, or use Command-K and search "Manage participants". Learn more about managing participants.
You'll find the "Mark priority", "Export conversation", "Show conversation events", ‚ÄúSnooze‚Äù, and ‚ÄúClose‚Äù actions are easily accessible from the conversation thread.
Assignment actions have moved to the right sidebar.
Tip: You can open and collapse this sidebar menu by using the keyboard shortcut Closed Bracket ( ] ).
You'll also find the ability to edit subject, convert to ticket, and create child ticket are available in the sidebar. (Note: you must have the "Attributes" app pinned to the sidebar).
The right sidebar is resizable and will remember your custom setting between page loads. It's used for the conversation split view, new conversation page, and new ticket page.

Tagging conversations can either be done by hovering over a message in the conversation thread and selecting the three dots, or by using Command-K and choosing to tag the first or most recent message:
This is a new layout enabling you to get a bird's-eye view of conversations. Access it anytime by using the shortcut key L or the toggle buttons on the bottom left of the Inbox.
Columns can be added and removed to quickly see exactly the information you want.
Direct actions like snoozing, closing, and re-assigning can also be done directly from the table.
You can choose to work in dark mode or light mode and easily switch between the two with Command-K:
Your inbox can be viewed in the following supported languages:
Change and set your preferred language with Command-K or via your workspace profile settings.
For a more focused view, you can choose to have the left sidebar closed here or by using the Open Bracket ( [ ) keyboard shortcut:
Items such as Teams, Teammates, Views and Dashboard have a new order:
You'll now find Inbox automation for Rules and Workload Management under Settings:
Lists of your Teams, Teammates and Views are edited and pinned by hovering over them and selecting/deselecting the pin:
Inbox Search looks a little different and the results are displayed in a table format:
You can choose to have the right sidebar open or closed here or by using the Closed Bracket ( ] ) keyboard shortcut:
Apps can be expanded and collapsed, or added and re-ordered like this:
Note: Conversation details (which contain conversation data attributes and the conversation ID) is now also an app which can be added or removed.
Find out which features are being built for the new Inbox next.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Can I use all the same features in the next-gen Inbox?
sections: We're still putting the finishing touches on some Next-Gen Inbox features. Below are a handful of features we've noted as absent from the Next-Gen Inbox
‚Äã‚Äã Removing an SLA from a conversation.
Closing a conversation from the conversation list.
Seeing a clear division between personal and shared macros.
Note: They are still divided, but the separation isn't shown when viewing them.
Adding conversation data attributes when bulk editing a conversation
Some right sidebar sections or features are not available yet, including:
Campaigns.External profiles (Only Pipedrive available)Total events.Subscription types.Company segments.Viewing the Brand in ‚ÄúConversation details‚Äù.
Note: Any of your private apps or third-party apps will still be available.

content.author:
Written by  Leanne Harte
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: How do Inbox seats work?
content.description: Enable your teammates to provide faster, more personal support by assigning them an Inbox seat.
sections: An Inbox seat is what a teammate needs to use the Inbox product. With a seat, you can:

Provide faster and more personal support, using the Intercom Inbox.Get more context about your customers, including previous conversations, company details, qualification data and more.Measure your team's performance with Inbox reports.Manually and automatically assign conversations to teams and teammates with seats.Automatically reassign conversations when you're away.Tag conversations.Create team inboxes.Create GitHub issues, automatically create leads in Salesforce.Reply faster with macros and smart inbox suggestions.
When you add the Inbox product, you'll get two seats straight away. You should assign your seats to the teammates who manage your incoming conversations.
Note: You can add as many additional seats as you need.
You can also add an unlimited number of teammates without seats to Intercom for free. They'll be able to access your conversations, but without the capabilities that Inbox seats give you.
Assign a seat to a teammate
To assign a seat, go to Teammates, and click 'Edit' on a teammate's profile:
Then, switch the toggle for Inbox to 'On'.
Note: If you've used your available seats, you can add more here too.
See how many teammates are using their seats, and who they are
From the teammates page, you can see the total number of used seats here:
And filter your teammates by whether or not they have a seat here:
What can a teammate without a seat do?
If you don't have a seat, you can't access the Inbox. Here's what you can do:
You can reply to conversations through Platform conversations.You can add internal notes and mention your teammates.You can be mentioned in conversations, and receive notifications when this happens.
And here's what you can't do:
You can't assign, or be assigned conversations.You can't tag conversation parts, create GitHub issues or create Salesforce tasks or leadsYou can't use macros or send articles in conversations.
Replying to conversations without a seat
You can access your conversations under Platform > Conversations.
Then, click on a conversation to reply to a customer or leave a note for a teammate:
If you're mentioned in a conversation you can receive a notification either in your browser or from the Intercom Conversations mobile app:
When you edit a teammate to remove their Inbox seat, you'll be asked who you want to assign their conversations to. You can assign their conversations to another teammate with an Inbox seat.

Organise your inbox by team, and create assignment rules to make sure conversations are answered by the right people.Switch on the conversation routing task bot to automatically identify and separate new leads from your customers.Automatically resolve common questions with Resolution Bot, so your teammates have more time to focus on conversations only humans can resolve.

content.author:
Written by  Ryan Quinn
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: When do Inbox rules fire in the next-gen Inbox?
content.description: Learn exactly when and how Inbox rules are triggered to get the best out of your Inbox automation.
sections: Inbox rules let you automate actions in conversations for an efficient inbox and optimal customer experience. This article explains the different ways rules can be triggered, and how they interact with Bots, Messages etc.
For a guide to creating and managing your Inbox rules, see this article.
When creating a new rule, you'll choose the point in a conversation when you'd like it to fire. There are seven events to choose from:
Note: It's possible for multiple rules to be triggered by a single conversation.
Then, when a rule is triggered it will check if the conversation matches the filters you've set:
If the conversation matches the filters, your rule actions will be completed:
When a customer starts a new conversation
If a user or lead starts a brand new conversation, rules based on this event will trigger. This includes:

New conversations in the Intercom Messenger. Started from your website, app or Help Center.New inbound emails.New direct messages from the Twitter, WhatsApp, Instagram, or Facebook apps.Conversations created with the REST API.
Replies to outbound messages.Replies to Custom Bots.Conversations started by negative reactions on your Help Center articles.

Important: This event only triggers rules on the very first message in a conversation. For this example, a rule based on the keyword ‚Äòprojects' would not match, as the keyword is not in the first message:

Important: If a new conversation is assigned to a specific team, teammate or 'unassigned' by a ‚ÄòCustom Bot from new conversations' or one of Operator's Task Bots, assignment actions in these rules will not assign the conversation again.
When a customer replies to outbound content
If a user or lead replies to an outgoing message or bot that was sent from your workspace, rules based on this event will trigger. This includes:
Replies to Chats, Posts & Emails (one-off or ongoing).Replies to Custom Bots for visitors, or users.Conversations started by negative reactions on your Help Center articles.
Replies to teammates in existing conversations.Replies to Custom Bots ‚Äòfrom new conversations'.Conversations started from articles on your Help Center.

If an outbound message or Custom Bot assigns a conversation to a specific team, teammate or "unassigned", assignment actions in these rules will not assign the conversation again. If a message or bot has no assignment rules, then assignment actions in these rules will assign the conversation to the inbox of your choice.
When a customer sends any reply
Whenever a user or lead sends any message in a conversation, rules based on this event will trigger. This includes:

The very first message from a customer in a new conversation.Any customer reply to an outbound message or Custom Bot.If a customer sends multiple messages in a row, these rules will trigger for each individual message.

Important: Assignment actions in these rules will re-assign the conversation, even if it has already been assigned by a Message, a Custom Bot or another Inbox rule. We recommend using caution before adding assignment actions to rules triggered when a customer sends any reply.
When a new conversation hasn't received a reply
When you create a rule based on this event, you'll specify one of the following time periods:

When a customer starts a new conversation, or replies to outbound content, a timer will start for the specified period. If there has been no reply from a teammate in that timeframe, rules based on this event will trigger. If a teammate replies before the time limit is reached, rules based on this event will not run.
Important: The time is only counted from the first message a customer sends, it will not reset after additional messages so rules based on this event will only run once per conversation.
When a customer has been unresponsive
When you create a rule based on this event, you choose the time period and if a customer hasn't responded to a teammate for that period of time, the rule will trigger:

Triggers when a new ticket is created by a teammate in the Inbox, or by a customer through the Messenger. This includes standalone tickets, child tickets, converting conversations to tickets, and ticket in bots.
When a teammate changes state of the ticket
Triggers when a ticket state is changed by a teammate in the Inbox.
Multiple rules can be triggered by one conversation or ticket
Because many rules can fire for a single conversation, it's important to understand which actions will occur, so you can prioritize your rules accordingly.

The first message triggers rules based on a customer starting a new conversation, or sending any reply.The second message triggers rules based on a customer sending any reply.After 5 minutes the conversation triggers rules for when a conversation ‚Äòhasn't received a reply in 5 minutes'.The teammate reply doesn't trigger any rules.
Tip: Read this article, and learn how to prioritize your rules correctly. üëå
Rules triggering in conversations with Bots
Rules based on when a new conversation is started, will trigger before Task Bots are sent in the conversation. This includes:
Sharing your reply time.Routing existing customers to support.Asking for contact details.Qualifying leads.Suggesting help articles.Getting context about issues up front.
Note: Rules based on when a customer sends any reply, will also trigger before Task Bots on the first message in a conversation.
Rules based on ‚Äòwhen a new conversation is started' will trigger before Custom Bots or Resolution Bot interact with the conversation, but only for non-assignment actions.
The rules will trigger again after the Bot interaction is complete, and assignment actions will occur, if the Bot hasn't assigned the conversation.

Rules based on ‚Äòwhen a customer sends any reply' will also run before the bot interaction, but will assign the conversation, even if the Bot has assigned it. These rules can assign conversations out of the bot inbox.
If a conversation is assigned to the Bot inbox, any rules based on when a customer hasn't received a reply, will begin counting down after the conversation is assigned out of the Bot inbox.
Other things to keep in mind
Inbound emails to a specific teammate
If a conversation is started by a direct email to a teammate's Intercom email address:

Rules based on when a new conversation is started will not perform any assignment actions.Rules based on when a customer sends any reply will run assignment actions, and may re-assign the conversation away from the teammate.
Rules triggered by the REST API

You can manually trigger rules to perform assignment actions with the ‚Äòrun_assignment_rules' API endpoint. A POST request to this endpoint will have different behaviour depending on if the conversation is inbound (started by a customer message) or outbound (started by a bot or outbound message):

Inbound conversations will run the assignment actions from rules that trigger when "A customer starts a new conversation‚Äù.Outbound conversations will run the assignment actions from rules that trigger when ‚ÄúA customer replies to outbound content".

content.author:
Written by  Matthew Pelyhes
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Can I delete a reply I send to a user?
content.description: Delete replies to conversations that you sent in error.
sections: Yes, you can delete a reply you've sent to a user in error. For example, if you include sensitive information in a reply, you can delete it so the user will no longer see it.
You can also delete replies your user has sent to you.

Note: Replies sent by email can't be deleted from your user's email client. If your user doesn't see your reply in the Messenger within two minutes, an email notification with the conversation will be sent to the user - which you also can't delete.
To delete a reply in the inbox, click the ‚Äòactions icon' next to the message.
You'll be asked to confirm your choice. This helps ensure you don't delete a message by accident.
Note: You can't retrieve any messages you delete.
Your user will now no longer see the message. Here's how it will appear to them in the Messenger:
Here's how the deleted message will appear to you in the inbox:
Note: The ability to delete replies is available to teammates with full permissions.
Read more about composing a message.

content.author:
Written by  Beth
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: How do I download a transcript of a conversation?
content.description: Easily share or keep record of a conversation by downloading the transcript.
sections: If you need to share a conversation, or keep a record of it, you can easily download its transcript.
Just go to a conversation and click the options icon, then click ‚ÄòExport conversation as text':
The conversation transcript will now download as a .txt file.
Your users and leads can also download a conversation transcript while they chat to you in the Messenger:
Note: Conversation transcripts are only available on desktop in the Messenger.

All replies in the conversationThe timestamps of every replyThe date and time the conversation was created (in your workspace's timezone)Operator's repliesThe customer and teammate's namesThe date and time the conversation was downloaded
The different states of the conversations (snoozed, unsnoozed, closed)Seen/unseen notesInternal notesHow and when the conversation was assignedCC/BCCImagesAttachmentsGIFsArticlesApps
Images, attachment, GIFs, articles and apps will be labelled as text in the file, like [GIF] and [Article - article name], for example.
Note: You can't export multiple conversation transcripts from your workspace but you can use our API to do so using our Conversations API.
To gain a better understanding of your team's support activity and performance, check out your Inbox reports.

content.author:
Written by  Beth
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Does Intercom have keyboard shortcuts?
content.description: Speed up your workflow in the inbox by using keyboard shortcuts.
sections: Yes, the team inbox has several keyboard shortcuts that let you perform common actions without using your mouse.
Click the shortcuts icon in the text box to expand and scroll to locate 'Keyboard shortcuts' to pull up a menu of available options. Or, use Command K to access.
To access the Command-K action menu, simply press the following keystrokes:
‚åò + K on Mac.Ctrl + K on Windows.

Note: Direct shortcuts are supported on English (QWERTY), French (AZERTY), Brazilian Portuguese, Latin American Spanish, Russian, Hebrew, and other non-Latin language keyboards using Chrome or Edge browsers.
To learn more about the shortcuts available see How to Use Command-K in the next gen Inbox.

content.author:
Written by  Leanne Harte
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: How do I block spam in the next-gen Inbox?
content.description: How to block and unblock users, and view your spam list.
sections: You can delete any abusive, offensive or spammy users by blocking the user who sent the message. Just select the dropdown from the top right corner of their user profile and click 'Block.

All of the information stored about that user, including their messages, will be archived from Intercom. The user can only be restored manually by you and any new messages from that email address will be rejected. The user will also be prevented from creating a new user account in the future.
Important: The web integration will now return a 400 error whenever a blocked user's data is passed to Intercom via ping.

If, however, you block a user by accident, you can easily unblock them. Just go to your app settings and select Blocked people from the left-hand menu under the General section. You'll see a list of your blocked users. Hover over a profile to select 'Unblock' on the profile you would like to reactivate. Your user's information will now be restored.
After you unblock the user, they'll immediately return to your user list.
Note: If they don't appear in your user list immediately, hard refresh your page.
Intercom has built-in spam filtering. We assign all our inbound emails a score and will filter anything that we deem to be ‚Äúspammy‚Äù.
If you're missing some messages that you think may have been incorrectly filtered, you can check the Spam folder from the Inbox,".

You will find any messages filtered as spam in this folder. If any have been filtered incorrectly, you can mark the message as ‚ÄòNot Spam' and send it back to the inbox it was originally intended for.

content.author:
Written by  Beth
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: How do I remove company email addresses from group conversations?
sections: When your customers CC people into a conversation your company's support addresses (e.g. support@exampleapp.io) are often included. You'll need to mark these addresses as ‚Äòcompany addresses' to let us know to ignore them.
In your email forwarding settings, you can add as many company addresses as you'd like us to ignore. Once added, they won't appear in group conversations.

Tip: Intercom will attempt to automatically detect and add any email addresses you forward to your inbox, as company email addresses in this list. You'll see "Automatically detected" next to the address when this happens:

content.author:
Written by  Ryan Quinn
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Can I start group conversations in the next-gen Inbox?
sections: Yes, when you're chatting to a customer, you can loop another customer into the conversation. This is useful if you're chatting to a customer and they need to get a colleague's input on a specific issue, like pricing for example. Here's how it works;
Simply click on the name in the composer and then you should be able to input another contact to add them as a participant.
Learn more about managing group conversations here.

Note: When you add people to a conversation, your company's support addresses (e.g. support@exampleapp.io) are often included. You'll need to mark these addresses as ‚Äòcompany addresses' to let us know to ignore them.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Tickets explained
content.description: Go beyond simple live chat ‚Äì handle complex customer requests asynchronously.
sections: As you scale, so does your conversation volume and not every customer request can be handled in a live chat. That's where tickets come in. Tier 1 support reps stay focused on getting to simple queries quickly, while Tier 2+ teams can be responsible for carrying out escalations or operational tasks for customers in the background using tickets, all within Intercom.
This results in streamlined workflows, reduced lag time, better visibility into progress for all teammates and customers, and improved reporting on volume, efficiency, and productivity.
Tickets open up a completely new way to use Intercom
Use the Inbox to create tasks for internal teams on behalf of customers, without the need for a message to be sent from or to the customer.
Important: Tickets can only be used with Intercom's Next-Gen Inbox. Your whole workspace must be fully migrated to this Inbox before you can start using tickets. Find out how.
Create a completely async communication channel in the Messenger and remove the customer perception that the Messenger is for live chat only.
Create tickets on behalf of customers when the request was not made via an Intercom conversation
Your support reps can create tickets to capture requests on behalf of customers and seamlessly pass these on to the right team.

An account manager had a meeting with a customer who requested a change to their subscription plan.The account manager creates a standalone ticket in the Inbox on behalf of the customer.An automation rule assigns it to the operations team.The operations team works through their backlog using an Inbox view with a table layout optimized for subscription plan change requests.The ops teammate can discuss the request with the account manager using internal notes.This ticket is added to the tickets report so the volume of different types of requests and how efficiently they are handled can be monitored over time.
Share responsibility for tickets between a support rep and a back office team
Delegate tasks that must be completed by back office teams before the support rep can close the conversation with the customer.

A banking customer has experienced fraudulent activity on their account.They open a conversation with customer support via the app.A back office team with specialist training and system access needs to reimburse the customer's account.The support rep creates a fund transfer child ticket for the back office team to execute.The support rep is responsible for managing the conversation from beginning to end and remains the point of contact for the customer.When the customer follows up to check the status of their case the support rep can see the status of the child ticket and any notes left by the back office team.The support rep automatically receives status updates from the back office team and updates the customer proactively.This ticket is added to the tickets report so the volume of different types of requests and how efficiently they are handled can be monitored over time.
Let customers submit tickets directly from your website or app for async resolution
Configure tickets in bots to identify common customer requests and capture key details directly from your customers without involving a support rep.

A customer of an online travel agent wants to make an amendment to their flight.They open the Messenger, and interact with a Custom Bot that prompts them to fill in a form and submit their request instead of opening a live chat with a support rep.They receive confirmation in the Messenger and via email that their request has been assigned to the appropriate team to action, and they can track progress and follow up via email or asynchronous messaging.A teammate works on the ticket and replies are sent to the customer's email.
Escalate a live chat to another support team to continue over email

Make it quick and easy for your support reps to handover customers with complex queries and requests without leaving the customer waiting for a chat response, or duplicating conversations by moving from the Messenger to email.

A live chat ends up being too complex to resolve in real-time.The support rep hands it over to another support team by converting the conversation to a ticket.The customer receives a ticket confirmation in the Messenger and via email making it clear that the conversation will continue asynchronously with a different team and not over live chat.
Send tickets in the Messenger and Bots via mobile SDKs
Using the latest mobile SDKs, customers can receive ticket cards in a conversation, submit ticket forms, and keep track of progress directly in the Messenger, without leaving your app.
Important: Upgrade mobile SDKs to iOS14.0.0, Android 14.0.0, Cordova 13.0.0, React Native 4.0.0 to give customers the best experience submitting tickets in your mobile app.
Tickets are fully integrated into the Intercom support solution

Tickets work in Inbox automation rules to route to the right team, update ticket states, and more.Inbox views can be set up for any team to monitor and manage their tickets.A new Tickets report has been added to monitor volume and efficiency of tickets. (new charts coming to custom reports soon)Tickets can be used in Custom Bot flows for customers to complete and submit (Resolution Bot coming soon).All tickets have the same internal notes functionality as conversations so teammates can discuss and resolve the customer request internally.Tickets can be used in your mobile app via the Messenger.
To start using tickets in Intercom, you'll need to check whether your workspace has fully migrated to the Next-Gen Inbox.
Once you're using the Next-Gen Inbox, you can create your custom ticket types.
Note: To use tickets in the new Messenger, your workspace will need to be migrated to the Next-Gen Inbox and opted-in to the new Messenger.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: How to access tickets features
content.description: Which features are essential for using tickets effectively and how to request access.
sections: Tickets can only be used with Intercom's Next-Gen Inbox. Your whole workspace (every teammate) needs to be migrated to this Inbox before you can start using tickets.
Your workspace has not fully migrated to the Next-Gen Inbox if you have an option to "Revert to old Inbox":

If you can see this option (or you're still using the old Inbox), you'll need to migrate your workspace to the Next-Gen Inbox using the button below. This will take you through a simple bot flow and give you access to tickets.

Important: Once your workspace has fully migrated to the Next-Gen Inbox, you and your teammates cannot revert back to the old Inbox. All of your conversations, teams, Inbox rules, etc. will be carried over to the new Inbox. See what's changed in the Next-Gen Inbox here.
Click the button above to start using the Next-Gen Inbox with tickets now. üëÜ

If you're in the Next-Gen Inbox and you don't see the "Revert to old Inbox" option, you can go ahead and create your ticket types.To use tickets in the new Messenger, your workspace needs to be migrated to the Next-Gen Inbox and opted-in to the new Messenger.

content.author:
Written by  Brian Byrne
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Ticket examples
content.description: Get inspired with these ticket type examples and templates
sections: This article shows a range of completed ticket types for various use cases. Use these as a jumping-off point to create your own.
Ticket for escalating a request to a tier 2 team
Using a ticket like this makes it easy to escalate common technical questions to another team. Perfect for when you want to convert a conversation into a ticket.
Ticket to capture subscription update requests

This ticket could be used to capture various requests that originate outside the Inbox. For example, a customers could request a change to their subscription plan on a call. Their account manager could capture this request after the call by creating a standalone ticket.
Ticket for a back-office team to investigate

In this example, a customer reaches out because their card was stolen and payments have been made with it. The support rep creates a task for a back office team to investigate the issue and reimburse the money that was withdrawn fraudulently.
Ticket to capture a flight amendment request
This ticket could be used in a bot, allowing customers to submit their request directly without having to start a conversation.
Ticket to log what happened on a call
This is a nice example of using a standalone ticket to capture what happened on a call and log it as a ticket to progress the issue.
Ticket to log a request for a new laptop
The Intercom IT team uses this ticket to capture requests for laptop replacements. It's a great example of how you can use tickets internally at your company.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Create custom ticket types
content.description: How to create your own ticket types to collect the specific information you need.
sections: Before you can create tickets, you need to first create the ticket types you want to use. Ticket types define the data fields to be captured in the ticket and ensure all the information your team needs is available when they pick up the request.
Note: Only teammates with permission to ‚ÄúManage workspace data" can set up ticket types. See how to manage permissions here.
Go to Settings > Workspace data > Ticket types and click ‚Äú+ Create ticket type‚Äù:
Tip: Check out these examples of completed ticket types for various use cases.

A modal will appear asking you to provide a name, description and icon. Give it a meaningful name that describes the type of action the ticket is dealing with. This will be visible to customers if you share the ticket with them.
For example, you could create a ticket type called ‚ÄúAddress change‚Äù to capture your customers' change of address requests:
Ticket names and attributes don't get translated / localized in the Messenger even if you support multiple languages.Ticket type names can be no longer than 25 characters.
Once you've saved the new ticket type, you can choose to create attributes for this specific ticket type.
Attributes can take on different formats:
Text, List, Number, Decimal Number, Boolean, Data and Time. Required/Not required.Visibility (hide from form and/or hide from customer).

If you use a Text Type attribute, you'll have the option to make it multi-line. We recommend checking this for anything with more than 30 characters, otherwise it will appear cut off in the Inbox.Ticket data attribute names can be no longer than 191 characters.Ticket type and data attribute descriptions can be no longer than 255 characters.Each ticket type can have a maximum of 50 attributes.
Sticking with the address change ticket type as an example, we could add an attribute for ‚ÄúHouse number‚Äù using a ‚ÄúNumber‚Äù format to ensure the new house number is captured in the ticket:
Then specify whether this attribute can be seen or must be completed by the teammate in the Inbox, or by the customer in the Messenger in order for them to create a ticket:
Continue to add attributes for the information you'd like to collect with this ticket type.
You can go back and edit attributes later, just use the edit icon on the right hand side.
Note: Any edits and new attributes will appear on tickets created before the change was made.
You can archive (and restore) a ticket type you've created. Go to Settings > Ticket types and select the ticket type.
Then click the ‚ÄúEdit‚Äù icon next to the ticket type name and select ‚ÄúArchive‚Äù:
Note: If this ticket type has any dependencies (i.e. it's used in Inbox rules) you'll need to remove it from those places and then archive it.

Once a ticket type has been archived, teammates won't be able to create new tickets with them and customers won't be able to submit them through the Messenger. Existing tickets of an archived ticket type will continue to function as normal.
To restore a ticket type, go to Settings > Ticket types and select the ‚ÄúArchived‚Äù tab at the top. Then find the ticket type and click ‚ÄúRestore‚Äù:
When you've finished creating your ticket types and adding any attributes to them, your teammates can:
Create standalone ticketsShare responsibility with child ticketsConvert a conversation to a ticketUse tickets in bots

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Creating standalone tickets
content.description: Allow internal teams to raise requests on behalf of customers.
sections: Your support reps can create tickets to capture requests on behalf of customers and seamlessly pass these on to the right team. This enables other departments to take accountability for the customer requests that only they can resolve.

For example, a Relationship Manager at a B2B company is on a call with a customer who raises a bug they found in the product. The RM can log a ticket on behalf of the customer from the Inbox for an internal team to investigate.
Important: To enable support reps to create standalone tickets, you'll need to create ticket types first.
From the Inbox, click on compose to select the type of ticket you want to create from the dropdown:
Note: These ticket types are created by you on your workspace, you can create as many as you like.
Then fill in the ticket details. These fields are predefined by the ticket type attributes. Any fields marked with an asterisk are required before the ticket can be created.

Important: Tickets must be associated with a single user/lead/contact upon creation using the ‚ÄúCustomer‚Äù field. They can't be created for multiple contacts, a company or for zero contacts. If you want to share the ticket with more than one teammate in the workspace, you can add the additional teammates as participants after the ticket is created.
After you've completed the ticket details, you can choose to share the ticket with your customer.

Important: Shared tickets allow teammates to send replies and talk to the customer. The customer will receive an email as a receipt of their ticket, and status update emails as you work on it. If you'd like to use this ticket for internal use only, you don't need to select this option. Learn more about sharing tickets here.

Once the ticket is created, assign it to a team manually or automatically using Inbox rules. If you've created a rule, the ticket will instantly be assigned to the correct team as soon as it's created.
This ticket shows in the Inbox conversations and can easily be distinguished from standard conversations by the ticket icon:

If a ticket will be shared with a customer, have your team use notes to work through the issue internally. When a ticket is shared with the customer, they will see all the replies in the ticket so it's best to use notes from the start. Use ticket reporting to track metrics for your tickets.Create an Inbox view to monitor tickets of a certain type.

Conversation SLAs don't work for tickets. SLAs for tickets are not available, yet.Tickets must be associated with a single user/lead/contact upon creation using the customer field. They cannot be created for multiple contacts, a company or for zero contacts.
Automating ticket workflows with rulesViewing tickets in the Inbox Updating ticket state Reporting on tickets

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Using tickets in bots
content.description: Automatically capture complex customer requests to create tickets for your specialist support teams.
sections: When a customer has a problem that can't be resolved in real-time, you want an efficient way of gathering information for your specialist support team to work on their request. Configure tickets in bots to identify common customer requests and capture key details directly from your customers without involving a support rep.
Route these tickets to your specialist support teams and reassure your customers it's in good hands, with visibility of who's picked up their request and status updates as it progresses.
This ticketing system is completely integrated with the Messenger:

All inbound volume flows through one channel, even those that require asynchronous support.It uses bots and forms to collect structured data without the need to speak with a support rep.Receipts are issued for submitted tickets, to set customer expectations.Status updates are provided via in-app messages and email notifications.
Insert the ticket type at the end of a bot path
You can insert any ticket types you've created into a Custom Bot to start collecting customer requests and creating tickets automatically (tickets coming to Resolution Bot soon).
Simply insert the ticket type at the end of an existing bot path by choosing ‚ÄúEnd bot with - Ticket creation‚Äù:

Important: Tickets cannot be inserted as follow-up actions. They can only be added to end the bot path. For existing bots that you've set up to end with a follow-up action (or any other way), you'll need to delete this action before you can make the bot path end with a ticket.
Tip: Use Custom Actions and Objects in bots to retrieve live data from your external systems and present customers with information they can select from, e.g. their current flight details.
Then select the ticket type you created:

If a ticket type has no attributes, it can still be added to a bot, and the end user will be presented with the ticket card. Clicking on it will lead to the ticket form, which will only contain their email address field, and they will need to hit create ticket.
Note: You can't add any follow up actions after a pathway ends in a ‚ÄúTicket creation‚Äù. If you need to assign the ticket to a specific team, use Inbox rules.
Choose if you'd like to ‚ÄúDisable the composer‚Äù in the Messenger to stop further replies after a ticket is created:
Note: If you reply to the customer, the composer will be re-enabled so they can respond to you.
Now save and set your new bot path live.
You can see how this will look and work for customers in the Messenger by clicking ‚ÄúPreview‚Äù at the top of the bot builder:
Note: This preview will also create conversations and tickets in the Inbox if you interact with it.
A customer has a request that needs the business to take action.
The Custom Bot asks the customer to submit the details of their request via a ticket form.
The customer submits their request and is presented with confirmation that the relevant team will pick it up.
The customer also receives an email as a receipt of their ticket.
The team responsible for actioning these types of requests sees it added to their queue and starts working on it. See how to manage tickets effectively in this section.
The customer receives an email letting them know that the team has started working on their request.
You'll need to upgrade your mobile SDKs to iOS SDK14.0.0 and Android SDK 14.0.0 to give customers the best experience submitting tickets from your mobile app.
Using the latest SDK version, customers will be able to complete and submit ticket forms in the Messenger:

Important: If a customer is on an older SDK version, instead of sharing the ‚ÄúCreate ticket‚Äù card in the Messenger, the Custom Bot will share a text reply which requests the same information from the customer that they would've otherwise entered in the card.

If the Custom Bot has ‚ÄúDisable the composer‚Äù enabled to prevent replies after a ticket form is sent, Intercom will override this setting in case of an older SDK to allow the customer to reply with the ticket details you've requested.Teammates don't get any messaging in the Inbox when this happens, they'll just see a text reply from the customer instead of the ticket attributes.Upgrading to iOS SDK 14.0.0 and Android SDK 14.0.0 will resolve this.
Automating ticket workflows with rulesViewing tickets in the Inbox Updating ticket state Reporting on tickets

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Sharing responsibility with child tickets
content.description: Share responsibility for customer requests between your support and back office teams.
sections: Support reps can create a child ticket(s) from a conversation, allowing another team to take ownership of investigating and actioning the ticket. As the child ticket is progressed, the support rep gets progress updates to help them to communicate how things are going with the customer.

A customer reaches out through the Messenger because their card was stolen and payments have been made with it. The support rep creates a task for a back office team to investigate the issue and reimburse the money that was withdrawn fraudulently. The support rep maintains responsibility for the customer relationship throughout the lifecycle of the case, while the back office team maintains responsibility for investigating the case and reimbursing the customer.
Important: To enable support reps to create child tickets from the Inbox, you'll need to create ticket types first.
Use the right sidebar in the Inbox and select ‚ÄúCreate child ticket‚Äù:

In our example we're going to create a ‚ÄúSuspected fraud‚Äù ticket for a back office team to investigate. The support rep captures the required details in the ticket form and clicks ‚ÄúCreate child ticket‚Äù:

Note: Child tickets are for internal tasks and can't be shared with the customer. This means teammates can't reply directly to customers from child tickets, but they can still reply from the parent conversation. If you need to share the ticket with a customer, then convert the conversation to a ticket instead.
Once a child ticket is created, it can be accessed from a note in the parent conversation:

The link between the parent conversation and the child ticket is shown by the icon in the top left corner of the conversation. A direct link to the child ticket is also provided in the right sidebar ‚ÄúDetails‚Äù panel:

Clicking on the link takes you through to the child ticket. The link between the child ticket and the originating conversation is identified by the title and icon of the conversation. The ticket attributes are also shown in the right sidebar.
Note: To see the ticket attributes you must have the ‚ÄúAttributes‚Äù app pinned to the sidebar. The sidebar is resizable to make it easier to read the ticket details alongside notes.
The back office team now picks up the child ticket and updates the ticket state as they're working on it:

When the state of the ticket changes, a note is posted to the parent conversation to inform the support rep of progress on the child ticket. This re-opens the parent conversation so they can also keep the customer informed.
When a child ticket is closed, the parent conversation status remains unchanged. You can see the status of the child ticket in the right hand side bar.

Notes added to child tickets have no direct impact and can't be seen on their parent conversation (and vice versa). Notes are only posted to a parent conversation when the ticket state changes.There's no limit to the number of child tickets per parent.Both tickets and conversations can have child tickets, but only 1 level deep (no grandchildren!)
Automating ticket workflows with rulesViewing tickets in the InboxUpdating ticket stateReporting on tickets

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Converting a conversation to a ticket
content.description: Give customers confidence while they wait for their request to be picked up by another team.
sections: Make it quick and easy for your support reps to handover customers with complex queries and requests without leaving the customer waiting for a chat response, or duplicating conversations by moving from the Messenger to email.

When a support rep converts a live chat to a ticket in Intercom, it's really clear to the customer that their request has been logged and the conversation has moved to an asynchronous experience, allowing it to be resolved outside the chat.
There are two ways conversations can be converted to tickets:
A teammate converts a conversation to a ticket manually,A customer converts a conversation to a ticket using a ticket form.
Important: To convert conversations to tickets, you'll need to create ticket types first.
A teammate converts a conversation to a ticket manually
When you need to take a conversation async, you can convert a conversation to a ticket using the details in the right sidebar:

Note: The ‚ÄúAttributes‚Äù section in the details sidebar is an app. If you can't see it you need to ‚Äòpin' the app and ensure it's expanded. This app also includes your conversation details and Topics.
Choose the ticket type that you want from the dropdown menu. Learn how to create and manage your ticket types here.
We'll use a ‚ÄúSupport request‚Äù ticket type as an example. This prompts us to enter fields that the specialist team needs to work on the ticket:
Note: These fields are predefined by the ticket type attributes. Any fields marked with an asterisk are required before the conversation can be converted to a ticket.

Tip: If you want to escalate or reassign conversations to another team quickly, and you've already captured the request details in the conversation or notes, you can create a ticket type without attributes. Support reps won't need to capture any details on the ticket form before converting the conversation, and rules can be set up to automatically reassign the ticket to the right team.

When converting a conversation, the ticket is always shared with the customer so that they can see it has been submitted and receive updates in the Messenger and via email. See what this looks like for your customers here.
You can hide attributes you don't want customers to see in the ticket type settings.
Tip: If you'd like to track this ticket internally only, create a child ticket instead.
Then, a teammate from the right department picks up the conversation from their own queue where they can view the ticket details and mark it as ‚ÄúResolved‚Äù or close the conversation:

Note: If you have assignment Inbox rules set up for tickets, the ticket will get reassigned to the correct team once the conversation has been converted to a ticket. If you don't want this to happen and want to hold onto the conversation with the customer, we recommend creating a child ticket instead.
If they need more details, they can also continue the conversation with the customer by going to the ‚ÄúThread‚Äù and clicking on ‚ÄúReply‚Äù:
Then the ticket state can be set to ‚ÄúWaiting on customer‚Äù:
This will notify the customer in the Messenger and via email.
Tip: Use Inbox rules to automatically snooze conversations when the ticket state is changed to ‚ÄúWaiting on customer‚Äù.
A customer converts a conversation to a ticket by being sent a ticket form in the Messenger

When dealing with a customer request or issue via the Messenger, support reps can reassign the request to a specialist team by sending the customer a ticket form to fill out in the Messenger conversation.
For example, this person wants to request a new laptop and the support rep can't complete the request themselves:
The support rep uses Command-K to ‚ÄúSend a ticket form‚Äù in the conversation:
Note: Teammates will only see the option to send a ticket form if:

They're in a conversation (not a ticket), andThe conversation was started via Messenger (not email or other channels).The conversation is happening over the web, or on a mobile app that uses a Mobile SDK version that supports tickets.
The ticket form collects information from the customer that the specialist team will need to resolve their request.
When the customer submits the form, they're notified that a ticket has been submitted and reassured it'll be picked up by the relevant team.
Submitting the form converts the conversation to a ticket:
Note: The ‚ÄúAttributes‚Äù section in the details sidebar is an app. If you can't see it you need to ‚Äòpin' the app and ensure it's expanded.
Tip:Use Inbox rules to automatically route these tickets to a new team or teammate. This will also automatically reassign the ticket as soon as the customer completes the ticket form.

Creating a ticket is only available in the next-gen Inbox.  You cannot automatically convert inbound emails to tickets.You cannot automatically convert conversations to tickets if they are reassigned to a different team or teammate.You cannot automatically convert conversations to tickets if a Messenger conversation switches to email due to inactivity. You cannot send the end user a ticket form and have it create a child ticket.You cannot send a ticket form to an end user when starting a new outbound chat conversation.
Automating ticket workflows with rulesViewing tickets in the InboxUpdating ticket stateReporting on tickets

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Share tickets with customers and send ticket updates
content.description: Provide asynchronous information about the current state of a customer's ticket.
sections: Sharing a ticket means you're able to keep customers informed with instant updates about progress, and provide a great waiting experience while your team works on their request.
When a teammate converts a conversation to a ticket or creates a standalone ticket and selects ‚ÄúShare ticket with customer‚Äù the following notifications are sent:
A ticket card in the Messenger
This displays details of their ticket, along with any ticket attributes your team captured in a new conversation in the Messenger.
Note: Ticket attributes can be configured to be hidden from customers if there's information you'd prefer they didn't see.
The ticket card tells them which team or teammate is working on their ticket, and explains that they will receive updates via email.
Customers can click back to their conversation in the Messenger from here and reply or provide more information.
This acts as a receipt for their ticket and helps to make it clear that their request will now be dealt with asynchronously, once your team has picked it up and began work on it.

This notification will always be sent, even if the customer is currently viewing the conversation in the Messenger, and it doesn't have the same delay (2 minutes) applied to other email notifications.
Note: Emails are personalized with your company branding, however, if you have multi-brand, these notification emails will be sent unbranded.
Status update emails as your team work on the ticket
As your team works through the request, they can update the ticket's state, which sends your customer automated status update emails.

This keeps your customers in the loop with progress avoiding the need for them to follow up to ask what's happening. Increase trust in your business with customers and save your support reps' time. üëå

In-app notifications for tickets work similarly to notifications for conversations. Customers will see references to tickets in snippets, on the Home space, with badges, in the Messages space, and within any conversation that contains a ticket.
A notification will be sent if the status of the ticket is updated or if a message is sent within a conversation that contains a ticket. See examples below:
In-app notifications for tickets will use the same behavior as existing in-app notifications.
If a ticket status is updated, the customer will see an in-app notification as they would for any normal conversation.

Customers receive push notifications when a teammate sends them a reply in a conversation that contains a ticket, and also when the ticket state has been updated. For example, ‚Äú[Teammate name] has moved your ticket into in progress‚Äù.
Note: When a ticket is submitted by an end user at the end of a bot path, the messages sent by the bot (operator) are not included in the email notification, only the end user submitted response are.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Automate ticket workflows with rules
content.description: How to use Inbox rules to automate your ticket workflows.
sections: Use ticket types, states, and attributes to power Inbox rules and create seamless ticketing workflows for your team.

Triggers - on a teammate creating a ticket and a teammate changing the state of a ticket,Conditions - to target by ticket type, ticket state, and the values of ticket attributes, andActions - to set ticket state.
Note: Only teammates with the ‚ÄúCan manage rules‚Äù Inbox permission can create/edit rules for tickets.
Set up a rule to trigger on a teammate creating a ticket or changing the state of a ticket. To get started, go to Settings > Inbox automation > Inbox rules and add a ‚ÄúNew rule‚Äù:
Here, you can add an event when ‚ÄúA ticket is created‚Äù or when ‚ÄúA teammate changes state of the ticket‚Äù:
"A ticket is created" event will trigger when a new ticket is created by any method which includes creating a new ticket, converting a ticket and a customer completing a ticket form.
"A teammate changes state of the ticket" will trigger any time the state of a ticket is updated.
Route tickets to the right team
For example, we can route tickets to the right team by adding an event when ‚ÄúA ticket is created‚Äù:
Then adding a condition based on the ticket type we created for flight changes:
And assigning all ‚ÄúFlight change‚Äù tickets to the Flight amendments team:
When we ‚ÄúSave and set live‚Äù these ticket types will automatically route to the right team.
Snooze conversations when waiting on the customer
We can also automatically snooze conversations with tickets that are waiting for a customer response. Simply add an event when ‚ÄúA teammate changes state of the ticket‚Äù:
Then add a condition if the ticket state is ‚ÄúWaiting on customer‚Äù:
And add an action to ‚ÄúSnooze Conversation‚Äù until a specific time:
Now whenever a teammate changes a ticket state to ‚ÄúWaiting on customer‚Äù, their conversation will automatically be snoozed for the set time.
Important: Rules which use ticket states can only be applied to tickets or conversations with child tickets. You also can't create a rule to convert a conversation to a ticket.
Target by ticket type, ticket state, and the values of ticket attributes
It's also possible to target tickets with rules conditionally based on their type, state and values of their attributes.
To get started, go to Settings > Inbox automation > Inbox rules and add a ‚ÄúNew rule‚Äù:
Here, you can add a condition based on ‚ÄúTicket type‚Äù or ‚ÄúTicket state‚Äù:
For ticket type, the equality check can be is/is not/is unknown/has any value, based on any of the ticket types you've created:
Tip: To target conversations only, set ‚ÄúTicket type is unknown" as the condition.
For ticket state, the equality check is also is/is not/is unknown/has any value, based on the ticket states ‚ÄúSubmitted‚Äù, ‚ÄúIn progress‚Äù, ‚ÄúWaiting on customer‚Äù and ‚ÄúResolved‚Äù:
Important: Rules which use ticket states can only be applied to tickets or conversations with child tickets. You also can't create a rule to convert a conversation to a ticket.
Or, you can target specific attributes from each ticket type you've created. Simply search for the ticket type and the attributes will be listed below it:

If one of these is selected, tickets with that type and matching attribute value will be targeted by the rule. For example, we could conditionally target ‚ÄúFlight change‚Äù tickets where the customer wants a return flight within 2 days.
We'd select the attribute ‚ÄúDesired date & time of return flight‚Äù under the ‚ÄúFlight change‚Äù ticket type heading:

Note: The comparisons here depend on the attribute's format (same as Conversation Custom Data Attributes). For example, attributes using list format only have the ‚Äúis‚Äù or ‚Äúis not‚Äù comparisons, whereas attributes using string format have more available such as is/is not/contains/starts with, etc.
These tickets can now be automatically routed to our Flight amendments team and marked as ‚Äúpriority‚Äù:
Add an action to set ticket state
Use an action to automatically set ticket states based on a rule. To get started, go to Settings > Inbox automation > Inbox rules and add a ‚ÄúNew rule‚Äù:
Here, you can add an action to ‚ÄúSet ticket state‚Äù:
For example, we could automatically change ticket state to ‚ÄúIn progress‚Äù when it's assigned to a teammate:

Note: If the ‚Äúwhen‚Äù or ‚Äúif‚Äù conditions are set up such that the rule matches a conversation without a ticket, the action won't do anything because the conversation doesn't have a ticket to change the state of.

Create Inbox views for tickets and switch to table layout for effective ticket management.Update the state of a ticket to keep everyone informed on progress.Explore your tickets report and create your own custom reports using ticket data.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: View tickets in the Inbox
content.description: Create views of tickets for specialist teams and switch to table layout for effective ticket management.
sections: With different tickets assigned to multiple teams, you'll need an easy way for your teams to view their tickets, and you'll want to quickly check on their status and see how they're progressing in the Inbox.
Easily identify tickets in the Inbox by the ‚Äúticket‚Äù icon:
Set up Inbox views for the team
Teammates can create a custom view to see all their tickets in one place. For example, you can use views to filter conversations with a ticket based on a ticket's state and type:
Note: Teammates need the Inbox permission ‚ÄúCan manage views‚Äù to create views in the Inbox.
Select from any ticket types you've created on your workspace:
Ticket type can be compared as is/isn't/has any value/is unknown:
Note: ‚ÄúIs unknown‚Äù means it has no value and will exclude any ticket from the view (leaving only conversations).
Available ticket states you can select from are Submitted, In progress, Waiting on customer and Resolved:
Ticket state can also be compared as is/isn't/has any value/is unknown:
To filter by specific ticket attributes, you'll find each ticket type has its attributes listed underneath:
For example, we could filter by ‚ÄúFlight number‚Äù that starts with a specific airline code:

Note: The exact comparison you get for each ticket attribute depends on its format and follows the same pattern as Conversation Custom Data Attributes. For example, a ‚Äúlist‚Äù format would only give you an ‚Äúis‚Äù or ‚Äúis not‚Äù comparison.
You can refine the view further by using and/or to add more filters:
When you've finished adding filters, click ‚ÄúSave‚Äù to save this as a new Inbox view.
Now your team can pin this view to their Inbox and quickly see only these conversations:

Note: Dedicated Inbox views for individual teammates tickets need to be set up manually. There is no out-the-box view for showing just tickets without conversations, or ‚Äútickets I created‚Äù or ‚Äútickets I participated in‚Äù
Switch your Inbox view to table layout
Table layout is great for getting an overview of tickets and can be configured to display only the columns of data you'd like to see.
To switch to table layout, use the button in the bottom left of the Inbox (or shortcut key ‚ÄòL'):
Now easily customize it using the tabs at the top to see the data that's important to you:
Click on a row to preview the ticket details in the right sidebar:
Update the state of a ticket to keep everyone informed on progress.Explore your tickets report and create your own custom reports using ticket data.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Update ticket state
content.description: Update the status of a ticket to keep everyone informed on progress and enable effective reporting and monitoring.
sections: Ticket states represent where a ticket stands in its lifecycle and help keep your team and your customers informed about progress on the way to resolution.
Tickets can be in one of the following states:

Submitted - Ticket has been created but is not being worked on yet. Every ticket initiates with this state but can't revert back to this state.In progress - Ticket is being worked on by a teammate.Waiting on customer - Customer input is required to move forward with the resolution. As soon as the customer responds, this state reverts back to ‚ÄúIn progress‚Äù.Resolved - Ticket is resolved.
Note: Ticket states can't be customized.
Changing the state of a ticket
Teammates can change the state of a ticket when they are viewing a conversation, replying to a conversation, or from the table layout and split view.
Note: This only works for replies, adding a note and changing the ticket state at the same time isn't available.
When closing a conversation with an open ticket, you'll be prompted to close the ticket with two options:

Continue without resolving - This will close the conversation and leave the ticket in its current state.Resolve and close - This will close the conversation and  automatically update the ticket state to ‚ÄúResolved‚Äù.

If a Conversations Data Attribute (CDA) is set to ‚ÄúRequired to close‚Äù, and that CDA is visible to the team assigned to the ticket, then the ‚ÄúResolve and close‚Äù modal will not show, the ‚ÄúRequired details‚Äù modal will show instead.If you bulk close conversations, you will not get this pop up to ‚ÄúResolve and close‚Äù so conversations with tickets could be closed without resolving.
Tip: Always resolve a ticket when closing a conversation for accurate ticket reporting.

When the state of a child ticket changes, a note is posted to the parent conversation to inform the support rep about progress made on the child ticket. The parent conversation is re-opened as a result.
For better visibility and management, ticket state can be added as a column in table layout:
Ticket states in the Inbox conversation
Changing the ticket state is added as a conversation event. This is seen by clicking the 3 dots at the top of a conversation and selecting ‚ÄúShow conversation events‚Äù:
Creating views for tickets in certain states
