content.title: Resolution Bot Answer reporting
content.description: Filter Resolution Bot answers performance metrics by a specific date range.
sections: Understand how Resolution Bot answers perform over the time, with the date range filter on both the Answers list and Answer details page.
The Answers list supports filtering performance metrics by date range.
Simply click on the date range on the right to filter the metrics of each answer in the table.
Note: The default date range is always set to ‚ÄúSince went live‚Äù.
The date range filter is also supported in the Answer details page. Go to an Answer and click on the ‚ÄúResolved‚Äù tab, then you can filter the date range.
When the date range is applied, the graph and the conversation cards will be updated.
Note: The default date range is ‚ÄúPast 2 years‚Äù.

content.author:
Written by  Jasmine Jaume
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Choose the next step for customers when a Resolution Bot answer is presented
content.description: Determine the next steps available for customers presented with an answer
sections: You can now choose what should happen when an answer is presented in Resolution Bot. This can be helpful when certain answers indicate that a conversation needs to be routed to a teammate, or when you think there is no further support that can be taken on a subject.
The three options available and their meaning:

Show standard reply buttons: this is your default option and presents the standard buttons at the end of the answer, available for your customer to choose from: ‚ÄòTalk to a person', ‚ÄòThat helped'..Pass the conversation to a teammate: when you believe a human is best suited to assist. When selected, this answer will no longer present the standard reply buttons and will pass the conversation to a teammate. You can choose to apply actions and rules. Resolve the conversation: when you believe no further help on the subject can be presented and want to automatically mark the conversation as resolved. Your customer will not be presented with the standard reply buttons. Note: as this option does not present reply buttons, no rules in place from previous Custom Bots will apply, as the conversation is not being passed to a teammate
Each answer you create can have its own ending, giving you greater flexibility in how you want the bot to behave.

content.author:
Written by  Anthony Lopez
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Path building in Resolution Bot
content.description: Answer and automate complex customer questions all in one place!
sections: With path building in Resolution Bot, you can answer more complex FAQs that require more information before a relevant answer is presented.

Edit an existing Answer or create a new Answer as normal.When composing your answer in Step 3, beneath the text box there is an option to continue the bot with reply buttons. To continue the bot by building a path, select "Continue" then input the reply options that you'd like your customers to be able to select. In the example below, you'll see we have the option "Yes" and "No thanks!" however, you have creative discretion to decide the text of your reply buttons.

3. After creating the reply buttons you can create the Next Path that a customer should be led to. To create a path, simply click into the greyed text box and click "Add path". As you'll see below, I've created a few different options for paths that a customer may go down.
Paths added to your Answer will appear in the left-hand menu.

4. Continue this process until a path within an Answer should end. Then, decide if the bot should end with the standard reply buttons, pass the conversation to a teammate, or resolve the conversation.

content.author:
Written by  Damon Alexander
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Let Resolution Bot follow up after Custom Bots and messages
content.description: Increase Resolution Bot's coverage by letting it follow up after messages and Custom Bots
sections: If you use Resolution Bot to answer common questions, you can let it respond when customers reply to your Custom Bots and ongoing messages, and attempt to automatically resolve even more conversations.
Resolution Bot can follow up to any ongoing chat or post message, just click "Add follow up action" and select "Let Resolution Bot respond".
After Resolution Bot has provided an answer, the conversation will be assigned to the team or teammate selected under ‚ÄòReplies assigned to':
Note: If the conversation was successfully resolved, it will be assigned to this team or teammate, and closed.
At the end of your Custom Bot path, if you'd like Resolution Bot to follow up, just choose to end the bot with ‚ÄòResolution Bot and follow up actions':
Then, add an additional bot message prompting your customers to ask their question:

After they ask their question, Resolution Bot will take over and attempt to resolve the conversation. üëçIf Resolution Bot provides an answer and you have the bot inbox enabled, your inbox assignment rules will apply after the bot interaction.
With the bot inbox disabled, your inbox assignment rules will apply before Resolution Bot sends an answer.
You should also add a follow up action for any conversations where Resolution Bot doesn't have an answer, like assigning the conversation to your support team:
Important: The follow up actions will only apply in conversations where Resolution Bot doesn't enter the conversation.
Ensure Resolution Bot has been trained effectively.Measure Resolution Bot's performance.Triage inbound conversations with Custom Bots.

content.author:
Written by  Damon Alexander
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: When should I use Resolution Bot's qualifiers?
content.description: Send answers only when customers use specific words in their question.
sections: If you'd like an answer to send only when specific words are used in the question, use qualifiers.
Most answers don't require qualifiers. By adding them, the answer will only send for questions that contain those words, and not for any similar questions without them.
Important: The presence of qualifiers in a question doesn't guarantee an answer will send.
To add qualifiers, click on ‚ÄòConfigure qualifiers' when training Resolution Bot:
You can then add qualifiers, either in a row, or separated by commas:

If you'd like the answer to trigger for any of your qualifiers, put commas between them. A comma works as an ‚Äòany' rule.If you'd like your answer to trigger only when all qualifiers are in the question, don't use commas. Words separated by spaces work as an ‚Äòall' rule.
Once you've saved your qualifiers, your answer will only send to questions containing those words.
Important: For qualifiers to work, you'll also need to add at least one example question, either from Resolution Bot's suggestions or manually:
You should also ensure that the words in your example questions correspond with the qualifiers you add.
Read this article to learn how to create effective answers.

content.author:
Written by  Laura Jolly
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: When does Resolution Bot send a message?
content.description: How Resolution Bot engages with your customers.
sections: Resolution Bot, our bot that instantly resolves common questions, sends a reply in these scenarios:

Resolution Bot replies to new conversations initiated by users/leads. Resolution Bot can respond when a user or lead replies to an ongoing message.Resolution Bot can follow up after a customer interacts with a Custom Bot.Resolution Bot responds in the Messenger on the web and in mobile apps. It won't reply in conversations started by email.Resolution Bot currently does not send replies in conversations started from articles in your Help Center ‚Äî It may reply to conversations started from the home page of your Help Center.If you've set audience filters on an answer, Resolution Bot will only send it to people who match those filters.Resolution Bot won't answer questions during conversations - it only answers questions in a new conversation, before your team replies.Resolution Bot currently supports 38 languages, it may not reply in conversations started in unsupported languages.If a user asks the same question again, Resolution Bot will answer. It will acknowledge that the answer has already been seen, and reiterate that this is the best available answer.
Resolution Bot can also suggest relevant answers while your customers type, before they send a message. Find out how to enable this here.
When Resolution Bot may not send a message

Qualifiers don't cause an answer to fire, but rather allow them to fire. The absence of qualifiers in a customer's question will guarantee that Resolution Bot won't run, however the presence of qualifiers in a customer's question does not guarantee that it'll send a message.

This is because you wouldn't want an answer to be sent based on a particular word. For example, you've created an answer about resetting your password and you added "password" as a qualifier. The majority of queries might be ‚ÄúI forgot my password‚Äù and this answer would be relevant, but there might also be a lot of queries that contain "password" and it wouldn't make sense to send them a reset your password answer.

Whenever a query comes in where Resolution Bot didn't send an answer you feel should've triggered, add this query as a training example. Be consistent with these - the more you add, the better your bot will be.
Resolution Bot becomes more accurate if you create several answers relating to the same topic. For example:
How do I add a task?How do I delete a task?How do I edit a task?

These questions are related to the same topic (tasks), but they're asking about different elements of it (adding / deleting / editing). Writing separate answers for each of the three types of questions, rather than writing one answer to cover all three questions, will help Resolution Bot send a message at the right time and respond more accurately.
Note: Resolution Bot doesn't consider capitalization - the suggested examples you see are from your customers' queries - it's just suggesting that these might be a good fit for your trained examples.
If a customer expresses that they'd like to speak to a person on your team, Resolution Bot responds intelligently:

In "one-time" mode (with looping disabled) Resolution Bot will not respond, and the conversation will be immediately assigned to your team.With looping mode enabled:If customers have access to support from a teammate, the conversation will be assigned to your team.If customers do not have access to human support, they'll be sent a link to additional help resources.
Read more about Resolution Bot here.

content.author:
Written by  Damon Alexander
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: How does Resolution Bot work with assignment rules, SLAs & reports?
content.description: Resolution Bot routes conversations based on your assignment rules.
sections: When Resolution Bot provides an answer to a customer's question, it will immediately route conversations based on your assignment rules. This means the conversation will be visible in a team or teammate's inbox. If you'd like to keep bot conversations out of the way, you should enable the dedicated bot inbox. Learn how to enable the bot inbox.
With the bot inbox enabled, assignment rules will only be applied after the customer has finished interacting with Resolution Bot. This happens:
When they click ‚ÄúThat helped üëç‚Äù or ‚ÄúWait for the team üí¨‚Äù.When they send a new reply after Resolution Bot's answer.
3 minutes after they stop interacting with the bot.
Enabling the dedicated bot inbox also lets you exclude bot time from your SLAs and certain Inbox reports. Read on to find out more.
Even when Resolution Bot successfully closes a conversation, it will still be assigned to the right team or teammate's closed conversation list.

By default the time Resolution Bot spends handling a conversation is included in your SLAs, but you can exclude this time from your SLAs with the bot inbox enabled. Just tick this box when enabling the bot inbox in Operator > Settings:
Find out more about SLA rules here.

In your Inbox reports, the ‚ÄòTime to close' and ‚ÄòFirst response time' metrics will include the time Resolution Bot and Custom Bots spend handling a conversation by default. You can see these metrics without bot interactions by enabling the dedicated bot inbox.
With the bot inbox enabled, you'll see a new filter on the following Inbox reports:
Toggling this filter will change the values in the report to include or exclude the time a conversation spends in the bot inbox.
Note: It's only possible to exclude bot time from your reports for the period since you enabled the bot inbox.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Custom Actions and Objects explained
content.description: With better bots comes better customer support that's faster, easier and super helpful.
sections: By integrating external data with Intercom bots, customers are able to self-serve effectively, while reducing inbound conversation volume and repetitive questions for your team. With Custom Actions and Custom Objects you can connect with external data in more flexible and customizable ways, so your customers can get immediate answers to even more questions.
Set up Custom Actions and Objects in bots in minutes and easily design personalized self-serve support experiences to suit your business, without code.

Custom Actions allow you to build no-code integrations to get live data and take actions in your external systems. Store this response data in Intercom and use it to power bot flows with Custom Attributes on:
Standard Objects - User and Conversation.Custom Objects - Your custom data type.

Custom objects provide more flexibility to model your customer data in a way that makes sense for your business - without the need for engineering resources  - helping you achieve more advanced automation in bots. Store any type of data in Intercom, such as Orders, Transactions, etc. and define the relationships between the data.
The power of external data in bots
Customers get a better support experience by reducing time to resolution, no longer needing to wait for human support.
Reduce inbound volume and free up agent time
By increasing the volume of queries that customers can self-serve, your agents can spend less time on repetitive tasks and more time on complex queries and high-value segments.
Empower your teams with a powerful bot builder
With integrations in place your team can build and update bots without using any code or the need for ongoing technical support.
Let your customers access more information in bots
You can now configure your bots to present new information back to your customers, as well as letting your customers take actions such as rescheduling deliveries or updating their contact details.
Teammates need no technical expertise to utilize that data in bots.
Our bots let you tailor the customer experience to give your customers a fast and relevant bot answer. For example, a bot message can be tailored based on a customer's order status.
Here are some of the key use cases to boost your bots and allow customers to self-serve:
Quick commerce - When will my order arrive?E-commerce - I want a refund / I need to change my delivery date.Utilities - See my meter readings.
Making use of the full power of this requires setting up:
Custom Objects to store data.Custom Actions to make external API calls and retrieve data / take actions.Using Custom Actions and Objects in bot flows.
Note: It's possible to use Custom Actions without Custom Objects. You can store data within an attribute on any of the standard objects in Intercom instead (People, Company, and Conversation).

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: 5 great ways to use Custom Actions and Objects in bots
content.description: Help your customers self-solve more of their questions with external data.
sections: From Quick Commerce, to E-commerce, to Utilities and more - every business can benefit from bots answering customers' questions automatically and effectively. Now it's more flexible than ever to integrate with external systems and use stored data to power your bot flows. Here are 5 ways you can use Custom Actions and Objects in bots‚Ä¶
To request and process a refund.
To choose from specific data, such as items, orders and accounts.

A great way to get started is to think of common questions that your teammates spend considerable time answering, using information currently not available in Intercom. Then use this information to power your bot flows by setting up:
Custom Objects to store data.Custom Actions to make external API calls and retrieve data / take actions.Using Custom Actions and Objects in bot flows.
Note: It's possible to use Custom Actions without Custom Objects. You can store data within an attribute on any of the standard objects in Intercom instead (People, Company, and Conversation).

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Setting up a Custom Object
content.description: How to model and store external data to suit your specific use case with Custom Objects.
sections: Custom Objects make Intercom more customizable by giving you a flexible way to import and model your external data, in a way that makes sense for your business, without the need for engineering resources or building custom integrations.

Once configured, you'll gain a more accurate, single customer view that makes all of Intercom's features more contextual, resulting in better customer experiences and more powerful capabilities for teammates. Using Custom Objects, you can build bots that resolve complex queries, create sophisticated support workflows, and save your support reps time in the Inbox.
For example, an E-commerce shopper could:
See their order status or delivery date.View multiple orders associated with their account and select one.Cancel an order.
To get started, go to Settings > workspace data > Custom object data.
Create your first Custom Object by clicking on ‚ÄúCreate new object‚Äù. Give the object a name (e.g. Order) and then click ‚ÄúSave‚Äù.
Note: The object name is how you'll identify it later in your workflows. It must be a unique name and once saved, it can't be renamed.
This creates a new parent object with some recommended default attributes:
You can add your own attributes by clicking on ‚Äú+ Create attribute‚Äù:
Select the format for this attribute. You can choose from:

Text - To display simple information such as order is ‚Äúcanceled‚Äù or ‚Äúopen‚Äù.Number - To display a numeric value such as an order ID.Decimal number - To display a numeric value containing a decimal such as order price.List - To display multiple values.Boolean - To display a value that is either true or false.Date - To display a date.Relationship - To link this object with another standard or Custom Object.
Give the attribute a unique name and describe what it does. In this example, we'll use boolean format to say whether an order has been shipped:
Note: The attribute name is a unique identifier and can't be renamed once you save it.
You can continue to create and save different types of attributes and these will appear under the Custom Object:
Relate a Custom Object to another object

To use the Custom Object in your bot flows and automatically present customers with object data they can select from, you'll need to create a relationship between your Custom Object and your other data objects (People and Conversation). Learn how to set up the right relationships for Custom Objects here.
Create a relationship between objects by clicking on ‚Äú+ Create attribute‚Äù again:

This time, use the format dropdown to link the object you created with People and Conversation data in Intercom. In this example, we'll start with linking to People data by selecting ‚ÄúLink Order to People‚Äù:
Note: Objects can relate to standard objects in Intercom (People and Conversation) and they can also relate to other Custom Objects once you've created them.
Then select the ‚ÄúRelationship type‚Äù from the dropdown options:

1 : 1 - This is when one object has a relationship with one other object, e.g. one user has one passport.1 : Many or Many : 1 - This is when one object has a relationship with more than one other object, e.g. one user to multiple orders.Many : Many - This is when an object can have a relationship with more than one other object, and vice versa, e.g. multiple orders to multiple products.
Important: The direction of this cardinality is very important when setting up relationships. Learn how to set up the right relationships for Custom Objects here.
For example, one customer might have multiple orders, so we would select the relationship type as ‚ÄúOrder is Many : 1 People‚Äù:

Then give each side of the relationship a unique attribute name that you can easily identify when adding it to workflows. For example, on the Custom Object ‚ÄúOrder‚Äù side, we'll add an attribute called ‚ÄúShopper‚Äù, and then we'll create another attribute on the ‚ÄúPeople‚Äù side called ‚ÄúOrders‚Äù:

Important: The attribute name is a unique identifier and can't be renamed once you save it. It may also be seen by a customer during a bot conversation so stick to customer-friendly naming conventions.
Now we've created both sides to the relationship. We can see it has been added to the ‚ÄúCustom object data‚Äù:
And it's also been added to the ‚ÄúPeople data‚Äù in Intercom:
Note: This relationship will appear under ‚ÄúConversation data‚Äù if you linked your Custom Object to Conversation.
Important: In order to use a Custom Object in a Custom Bot there must be a relationship to BOTH People and Conversation.
Populate a Custom Object with data values
Next, you'll need to populate your Custom Object with data. This can be done by:

Using a Custom Action to pull data in from an external system via a GET request.Using the Messenger JS snippet to pull data in from a webpage (temporarily unavailable until end of 2022).Via the public API (coming soon).
Custom Actions can be used to return an array of objects from an endpoint and then map the response data to a Custom Object. Learn how to set up Custom Actions here.

Use this Custom Object in your Custom Bots or Resolution Bot to provide customers with contextual support. Customers will be able to see and select from reply buttons in the bot flow based on the object data you have stored.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Setting up the right relationships with Custom Objects
content.description: Learn about the different types of relationships to accurately represent the complexities of your data.
sections: Custom Objects allow you to extend Intercom's standard object data (People, Companies, Conversations etc.) and store data that represents your business in a more flexible way. Relationships allow you to define how those objects are related to each other so that relevant data can be displayed to the right people.
Loom deep-dive into Custom Objects and Relationships

Here's an in-depth overview of how to set up a Custom Objects and configure the right relationships for an order example. Please feel free to comment or add question directly via Loom as we'll be updating this content periodically.
Next, we'll walk you through each type of relationship so you can find matches for even the most complex data without saying ‚ÄúIt's complicated‚Äù.

This is a more common type of relationship. For example, one or more orders can have just one shopper. Each order has only one shopper who made the order, and each shopper can be linked to many different orders. So you could create a Custom Object called ‚ÄúOrder‚Äù and create a relationship that links it to ‚ÄúPeople‚Äù data in a ‚ÄúMany : 1‚Äù relationship, allowing more than one order to be associated with one user.

People-Addresses (Each person can live at one address, but each address can have one or more people staying at it.)Department-Employees (Each employee belongs to one department, but each department can have one or more employees.)

Lastly, you can have a many-to-many relationship. For example, an order can contain one or more products, and a product can belong to one or more orders. So you could create a Custom Object called ‚ÄúOrder‚Äù, and another Custom Object called ‚ÄúProduct‚Äù and then create a relationship that links the two data types in a ‚ÄúMany : Many‚Äù relationship allowing order data to have more than one product data associated with it, and vice versa.

Projects-Contributors (Projects can have many contributors working on them, and the contributors can be working on one or more of the same projects together.)Students-Classes (Each student can attend many classes, and each class can have many students in it.)

One-to-one relationships are quite rare because it's unlikely that both sides of a given relation can be matched to one and only one counterpart. For example, you have lots of users in your system and you require them to provide passport details to book a flight. Assuming a user can only have one passport at a time, you would create a Custom Object for ‚ÄúPassport‚Äù with attributes for ‚Äúpassport_number‚Äù and ‚Äúexpiry_date‚Äù and then create a relationship which links it to the user.
Note: This relationship type is currently not supported.
Employee-Desk (Each employee is assigned to one desk, and each desk is intended for only one employee.)Country-Flag (Each country has only one flag and each flag belongs to only one country.)

Relationship types can be edited once you've created a relationship between two attributes. Please note that if you edit the Relationship type, all existing associations for this relationship will be deleted. This means bots and custom actions that use this attribute might fail.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Setting up a Custom Action
content.description: Learn how to create Custom Actions to integrate your external data with bots that resolve more customer questions.
sections: Custom Actions are no-code and deeply embedded integrations that can connect your live external data with Intercom. This live data can be used to power bot flows, allowing your customers to self-serve their queries automatically in the Messenger.

A great way to get started is to think of common questions that your teammates spend considerable time answering, using information currently not available in Intercom. These can be questions where your customers simply want to get information that you store on an external system such as, ‚ÄúWhat is my order status?‚Äù, or take action like, "Reschedule a delivery."
When you know which questions you want to solve, it's surprisingly simple and quick to set up a Custom Action with little to no technical expertise.
First, navigate to Settings and go to Apps & Integrations where you'll find ‚ÄúCustom Actions‚Äù:

This is where you'll set up all the different connections you have to external data (e.g. Shopify, Salesforce, etc.) depending on your use case. Click ‚ÄúCreate action‚Äù to set up your first Custom Action:

Give your Custom Action a unique name that explains exactly which action it will be taking (e.g. ‚ÄúGet order ID‚Äù). Use the description field to tell teammates when to use this action and what information they can expect it to fetch from the API server (e.g. ‚ÄúGet order for a given ID. Order ID should be stored in Conversation CDA‚Äù).
We'll use a common use case as an example: An E-commerce retailer uses Shopify wants to pull in the order information.
Next, fill in the request details. This is where you'll need to enter the API URL to the 3rd party system you're connecting to (e.g. Shopify, Salesforce, etc.).
You can specify what action you'd like this request to take by selecting the method:

GET - Read and store information from the 3rd party system.POST -  Create or add information to the 3rd party system.PUT - Update information in the 3rd party system.DELETE - Remove information from the 3rd party system.
Using the same Shopify example, we'll ask the request to GET information from the Shopify API and enter the URL:
Important: To make a request, the URL must be an HTTPS address and return a JSON response.

Note: You can insert attributes from User, Conversation, Company, and events as templated values in the URL and in the request body of POST, PUT and DELETE methods. Use custom data attributes you have already set up in your workspace. Or, for much greater data flexibility, try using Custom Objects.
You can choose to add any additional parameters to this request by selecting ‚Äú+ New key value pair‚Äù under HTTP Headers:

Custom Actions support both fixed and dynamic tokens for authentication. Under the Authentication tab, you can select the authentication token you want to use in the request, which will then be added to the header.
Next, you'll need to test this action to make sure it's fetching the right data from the 3rd party system you're connecting to.

Enter a test value (e.g. the order number) to check the Custom Action has been configured correctly. You should get a green tick and see the details of that request if the connection is validated with the API.
Tip: This is all the information you can now use to power your bots and provide customers with fast answers, such as order status.

Important: Testing this request makes a connection with the API so it will complete the action you have created. For example, if you've asked it to DELETE data from the API, this information will be deleted. Try testing with a GET request to ensure you're only reading information and not changing it.

This step is optional but it's important if you want to use the data in your bot flows, particularly for GET requests. It tells the action where to store this information in Intercom so that it can be given to customers in your Custom Bots or Resolution Bot as answers to their questions.

Note: Common scenarios where you might not need to store data are action request types PUT, POST, DELETE. For all GET requests, if you want to use the data in bots, you'll need to store this data in Intercom.
Learn about the handling of Custom Action storage, authorization and execution.
JSON response data can be stored in:
Standard Objects: User, Conversation and Company attributes.Custom Objects: Object attributes you have created in Intercom.
Select the Intercom object and then map it with the external API object.

Important: All custom attributes and Custom Objects must be created before they can be used for response storage here. Find out more about creating custom attributes, or learn how to store your data with Custom Objects.

Now select the data attributes in Intercom you want to store this information in. For the Shopify example, we selected ‚ÄúConversation‚Äù as the Intercom object and then selected the Conversation CDA in Intercom ‚Äúccda_shopify_order_fullfilment_status‚Äù and mapped it with the API attribute in Shopify: ‚Äúorder.fulfillment_status‚Äù:
Note: External data can only be stored in custom data attributes and not the standard data attributes.

We also added another object mapping for ‚ÄúPeople‚Äù and then selected the CDA in Intercom ‚Äúcda_shopify_order_fullfilment_status‚Äù and mapped it with the API attribute in Shopify ‚Äúorder.fulfillment_status‚Äù:
Mapping response data to Custom Objects
When mapping with Custom Objects, you must map the ID to the external_id field otherwise it will create duplicates with each GET request. Learn more about mapping relationships.
Find the supported JSON objects and arrays for response mapping here.
Once you've tested your Custom Action successfully, you're ready to set it live.
Now you can use it in Custom Bots or Resolution Bot to allow customers to self-serve with the information you've integrated. üéâ
Moving a Custom Action to draft
If you want to deprecate old Custom Actions that are no longer required, you can move them into draft state.
Find and click on the Custom Action you want to move to draft from Settings > Apps & Integrations > Custom Actions.

This will check for any dependencies on this Custom Action. You'll need to review and resolve these dependancies before moving it to draft state. For example, you may need to remove this Custom Action from a Custom Bot first.
Learn how to use Custom Objects to get more flexibility with how you structure and store your data.

content.author:
Written by  Stephen Forbes
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Setting up Custom Actions authentication
content.description: Approaches you can use to authenticate your Custom Actions, and how to set up, view and manage tokens.
sections: To set up new tokens, go to Settings > Apps & Integrations > Authentication to configure authentication methods which can be used in Custom Actions:
There are two authentication methods to choose from:
Text tokens are static tokens. You can set the value of the token, a prefix for the token, and the key for the header containing the token, which will be inserted into the Custom Action request.

HTTP Request tokens are able to dynamically refresh themselves. You can configure a HTTP request to your Authentication Endpoint. These need to be tested from the Authentication Token UI before they can be saved. Fields that affect the request itself are HTTP method, URL, HTTP headers, and the body.

If a HTTP Request token is assigned to a Custom Action, the action will use the most recently fetched token in the Custom Action. If the action fails with a ‚Äú401 Unauthorized‚Äù response, the token will be refreshed (by sending a HTTP Request to the configured URL) and the action retried with the newly fetched token.
If there's a problem refreshing a token the issue will be logged in the Custom Actions "Logs" tab:

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: JSON objects and arrays supported for Custom Actions response mapping
content.description: See which objects and arrays you can use for response mapping in Intercom.
sections: Objects and arrays you can map
Note: In order to map date data to a Datetime attribute on a Custom Object, we only support mapping strings with an ISO 8601 format, e.g. 2008-01-10T11:00:00-05:00
You can map root API object to User, Conversation and Custom objects. All API attributes are accessible.
You can map 3 API objects (root, order, client_details) to User, Conversation and Custom objects. All API attributes are accessible.

{	"order": {		"id": 450789469,		"admin_graphql_api_id": "gid://shopify/Order/450789469",		"app_id": null,		"browser_ip": "0.0.0.0",		"buyer_accepts_marketing": false,		"cancel_reason": null,		"cancelled_at": null,		"cart_token": "68778783ad298f1c80c3bafcddeea02f",		"checkout_id": 901414060,		"checkout_token": "bd5a8aa1ecd019dd3520ff791ee3a24c",		"client_details": {			"accept_language": null,			"browser_height": null,			"browser_ip": "0.0.0.0",			"browser_width": null,			"session_hash": null,			"user_agent": null		}	}}
You can map the root array to a Custom Object type. All API attributes of an element are accessible (the first element is taken as representative).

[	{		"type": "admin",		"id": "493881",		"name": "Hoban Washburne",		"email": "wash@serenity.io",		"away_mode_enabled": false,		"away_mode_reassign": false	},	{		"type": "admin",		"email": "mal@serenity.io",		"id": "646303",		"name": "Malcolm Reynolds ",		"away_mode_enabled": true,		"away_mode_reassign": false	}]
You can map access arrays nested inside of objects (not other arrays). You can map these arrays to Custom Objects.
Arrays nested inside of other arrays

You can't access arrays that are nested inside of elements of other arrays. This is because we don't know which element of the top level array to pick. So in the example below you can map the order array to a Custom object. But not discount_codes arrays as it's nested inside the orders array.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Using Custom Actions in bots
content.description: Answer more questions automatically with Custom Actions in your Custom Bots and Resolution Bot.
sections: Using Custom Actions you can personalize the automated experience in Custom Bots and Resolution Bot. Customers can get information quickly such as checking on their order status. We'll go through how to use your own Custom Actions in bots to streamline your unique workflows and enable better support for your customers.
Using Custom Actions in a Custom Bot
To build out your Custom Bot using Custom Actions, navigate to Operator > Custom Bots > From a new conversation and click on ‚ÄúNew Custom Bot‚Äù:
Note: It's possible to use Custom Actions without Custom Objects. You can store data within an attribute on any of the standard objects in Intercom instead (People, Company, and Conversation).
Choose to start from scratch with a ‚ÄúNew Custom Bot‚Äù:
Type your suggested reply based on the customer query you'll support with a Custom Action. In this example, we'll use ‚ÄúWhere's my order?‚Äù:
Now add a new path to collect information from the customer using a Conversation CDA you've created.
For example, we've created a Conversation CDA to get order information using an Order ID, so we added a new path called ‚ÄúGet Order by ID‚Äù:
In that new path, type the bot message to request information from the customer (e.g. ‚ÄúWhat's your Order ID?‚Äù) and then click on ‚ÄúAdd data field‚Äù:
Set the attribute to the Conversation CDA you've created ("ccda_shopify_order_id" has been used in this example):
Then add a step and select ‚ÄúCustom action (using API)‚Äù to call out to the Custom Action you've previously set up:

Tip: While the bot fetches the data from the API and returns it to the customer, add a follow up bot message explaining that this action is happening while they wait. For example, you could say ‚ÄúFetching your order details now, this could take a few seconds‚Ä¶‚Äù Or a fun GIF that demonstrates the same thing. This is where your personality and brand can make the bot flow feel more authentic for your customers.
Add a ‚ÄúSuccess‚Äù path which presents the customer with the information returned from the API, using the attributes you mapped in your Custom Action set up:

In case the action couldn't be completed, you'll also need to add an error path to handle those situations and tell customers what to do next (e.g. ‚ÄúSorry, that order was not found. Would you like to speak to a member of the team?‚Äù)
Pro Tip: Use conditional branching to ensure that the data field has a value, and a fail path for when customers leave the data field blank.
Finally, finish setting up the Custom Bot Rules, Scheduling and Goal to trigger your bot and then set it live.
Using Custom Actions in Resolution Bot
Custom Actions can also be used in Resolution Bot the same way. Set up the bot flow to call Custom Actions by going to Operator > Resolution Bot > Answers and creating or editing an Answer.
Then call the Custom Action you've set up.
Learn how to set up and train resolution bot to answer customer questions.
Use Custom Objects alongside Custom Actions to automatically present customers with external object data they can select from (e.g. multiple orders, IDs, items, etc.).

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Using Custom Objects in bots
content.description: Create fully flexible and powerful support experiences in your Custom Bots and Resolution Bot with Custom Objects.
sections: With the added flexibility of storing data in Custom Objects, your customers can automatically be shown information such as recent orders they've made, and they'll be able to select from this object data and even take actions on it such as canceling an order.
Let's get started. Navigate to Operator > Custom Bots > From a new conversation and click on ‚ÄúNew Custom Bot‚Äù:
Then choose to start from scratch with a ‚ÄúNew Custom Bot‚Äù:
Type your suggested reply based on the customer query you'll support. In this example, we'll use ‚ÄúWhere is my order?‚Äù:
Then click ‚ÄúChoose a path‚Äù and add a new path. We've added a new path to ‚ÄúFetch and display orders‚Äù and we'll use a Custom Action to retrieve this data in the next step.

Tip: While the bot fetches the data from the API using a Custom Action, create a bot message explaining that this action is happening while they wait. For example, you could say ‚ÄúFetching your order details now, this could take a few seconds‚Ä¶‚Äù Or a fun GIF that demonstrates the same thing. This is where your personality and brand can make the bot flow feel more authentic for your customers.
Then add a ‚ÄúCustom action (using API)‚Äù to add a Custom Action you've previously set up:

In case the action couldn't be completed, you'll need to add an error path to handle those situations and tell customers what to do next (e.g. ‚ÄúSorry, we couldn't find your orders. Would you like to speak to a member of the team?‚Äù)
Now go back to the display path and continue your bot flow with ‚ÄúData selection buttons‚Äù. This will allow you to add button options based on object data returned from the API:
Select from Custom Objects you have previously set up. In this example, we've created a relationship between Order and People objects, named ‚Äú_userOrders‚Äù to find a customer's existing orders:
Then decide which attribute to show on the reply buttons from the Custom Object you've set up. For example, we'll show the customer's order number:
Add a new path for the customer's selection:
Then choose the Conversation relationship attribute where this selection should be saved:
Note: You'll need a Conversation relationship attribute set up to store that information. Learn how to set up the right relationships for Custom Objects here.
In case the Custom Object data couldn't be found, the bot will automatically take the customer down a different path. Select the error path you created earlier (i.e. ‚ÄúCustom Action Failed‚Äù):
Now use the ‚ÄúNew path‚Äù you created to display the information the customer requested (i.e. ‚ÄúDisplay order details‚Äù) and add a bot message using your custom data attributes:
You can choose to end your bot flow here if you only want to give the customer information they requested. Just finish setting up your bot Rules, Scheduling and Goal and then set it live.
If you'd like to enable customers to take actions based on information they requested, you can continue the bot flow with conditions. This is super useful for cases where customers might like to:
Cancel an order.Request a refund.Submit a meter reading.
From the path where you displayed information, simply select ‚ÄúContinue bot with Conditions‚Äù:
For example, if we have shown a customer's order number and status, we can continue the bot flow down different paths depending on whether the order status was ‚ÄúDelayed‚Äù or ‚ÄúCompleted‚Äù:
Note: In case the information could not be retrieved from the API at that time, you'll need to add an ‚Äúelse‚Äù path that takes them to the error path you created earlier.
Now finish creating the new paths you set up. For example, we created a ‚ÄúDelayed‚Äù path if the order status was delayed, and then continued the bot flow with a ‚ÄúRefund‚Äù path:
This custom bot flow can provide as many different path options as you'd like to offer, depending on your specific use case.

Remember, you can also provide customers with an option to speak to a member of your team instead. For example, we added this as a reply option on our error path and then created a new path called "Speak to team" and ended that path by assigning the conversation to our Support Team:
When you've finished creating your custom bot, you'll need to set up the Rules, Scheduling and Goal before setting your bot live.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: How to manage Custom Objects
content.description: Find where to view, update, archive and manage attributes for Custom Objects.
sections: Once you've set up your Custom Objects, it's easy to manage them. You can view the parent object and the attributes created for each one, as well as update or archive them.
Manage Custom Objects and their attributes
To manage your Custom Objects, go to Settings > workspace data > Custom object data:
When Custom Objects are saved, they are added as rows in the ‚ÄúLive‚Äù tab and you can find details for:
Object - name of the Custom Object.Last updated - time elapsed since the Custom Object was last edited.Created - time elapsed since the Custom Object was first created.
To see the attributes created under each Custom Object, click on the edit icon:
You can view the details of individual attributes by using the edit icon next to each one.
Note: You can only edit the description of an attribute once it's created and saved, you can't change the format or attribute name.
Archive an attribute by clicking on ‚ÄúArchive‚Äù:

Note: Archiving an attribute prevents your team from using it. Its data will still be stored. If the attribute is currently used in workflows (e.g. Custom Bots) you'll need to remove it from those workflows before you can archive it.
To archive a Custom Object go to Settings > workspace data > Custom object data and click on the edit icon next to the object you want to archive:
Then select ‚ÄúArchive‚Äù in the upper right and again in the modal confirmation.

Note: Archiving a Custom Object prevents your team from using it. Its data will still be stored. If the Custom Object is currently used in workflows (e.g. Custom Bots) you'll need to remove it from those workflows before you can archive it.
Archived Custom Objects will appear under the ‚ÄúArchived‚Äù tab and can be restored easily by hovering over the object name and selecting ‚ÄúRestore‚Äù:

content.author:
Written by  Brian McKiernan
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: View Custom Object data in the Inbox
content.description: How to get additional data context in the Inbox through Custom Objects associated to user or conversation.
sections: Support reps working in the Intercom Inbox can view additional data context via Custom Objects associated to user or conversation.
Important: This feature is only available in the Next Gen Inbox.
Note: Custom Objects must previously be set up, in order for them to show in Inbox. For more on how to do this, check out:
Setting up a Custom Object.Setting up the right relationships with Custom Objects.
Custom Objects related to user showing in the sidebar

To see all Custom Objects related to user, expand the User data section in the sidebar and scroll to find the Relationship Attribute that was created linking the ‚ÄòUser' object and the ‚ÄòCustom Object'.
In the example below we can see two Custom Object records, ‚ÄòApple iPad Pro' and ‚ÄòApple iPad Air':
Tip: You can ‚Äòpin' the User attributes to the sidebar and make them easier to find.
On hover, the Custom Object record(s) name expands:
On click, the sidebar changes to a view of the Custom Object's attributes:
Custom Objects related to conversation showing in the sidebar

To see all Custom Objects related to conversation, expand the Conversation Details section in the sidebar and scroll to find the Relationship Attribute that was created linking the ‚ÄòConversation' object and the ‚ÄòCustom Object'.
Custom Object records that are associated to the specific Conversation in the Inbox will be shown:
Note: It's not possible to ‚Äòpin' attributes in the Conversation Details.
In this example, you can see the bot flow and Order selection matching the right sidebar:
Click on a Custom Object record to view its data attributes:
Configuration settings to improve display of Custom Object data in the Inbox.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Custom Actions security and best practices
content.description: Learn about the handling of Custom Action storage, authorization and execution.
sections: Tokens are stored as part of header configuration. For these values we encrypt data at rest. Read more about security at Intercom here.

Custom Actions support both fixed and dynamic tokens for authentication. You can set up and manage your authentication tokens that you want to use in the request, which can then be added to the header.

All request configuration (Body, URL and Headers) are encrypted at rest. All requests are sent by our backend. Which means we do not make any API calls from the browser. For example, when a user triggers an action, this action is triggered by the Intercom system and not the UI.

Important: Third party data is not validated by Intercom, and your Custom Action may overwrite data you've stored in Intercom. You should ensure that you trust the data that is returned from a Custom Action.
Here's how to make sure that you can create secure and safe connections with Custom Actions.
For the most secure call, we recommend using ‚ÄòEmail' or ‚ÄòUser ID' on the User Object to match the user in your system.
Intercom currently only allows you to provide verification of email or user ID values coming from the Messenger. We strongly encourage you to set up and enable Identity Verification.
There are generally two ways data can be compromised:

A user updates one of their own attributes maliciously - For example, setting "user_shopify_id=123", where 123 is a victim's shopify ID. Then this data is pushed or pulled from Shopify for ID 123 and it gets associated with the malicious user in Intercom.A user manipulates data in a third party, and a Custom Action pulls in compromised data to Intercom - For example, a user signs up for a third party using the phone number of a victim. Then a Custom Action queries the third party and syncs that phone number to a user attribute in Intercom. Now the user has overwritten their phone number with the victims.
To prevent this from happening, always test your Custom Action first before setting it live to ensure it's configured correctly. Key things to look at:
Make sure that your Custom Action is returning data relevant to the matched user.Make sure that your data is being stored correctly in your mapped Intercom attributes.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Custom Actions and Objects FAQs
content.description: Support and information for common questions around using Custom Actions and Custom Objects.
sections: How do I know if Custom Actions or Custom Objects are available to me?
Custom Actions are included on all plans at no additional cost. 15 Custom Objects and 100K records are available on all plans at no additional cost.
Will testing a Custom Action affect my data?
Yes, if you use the POST, PUT, or DELETE methods when testing a Custom Action it will perform those actions on your data. So, testing a DELETE call on a user will actually delete them.
Does data returned from an external system need to be stored in Intercom?

Storing data is optional, but if you want to use external data returned from a Custom Action in Intercom (i.e. bot flows), it needs to be stored as custom data attributes on standard or Custom Objects in Intercom. Learn more about Custom Actions security and best practices here.

Note: Common scenarios where you might not need to store data are ‚Äúaction‚Äù request types PUT, POST, DELETE. For all GET requests, if you want to use the data in Intercom, you'll need to store the data in Intercom.
Where is Custom Object data stored?
This data must be stored in Intercom.
Is it possible to update a Custom Object attribute?
You can only edit and update the description of a Custom Object and its attributes. If you need to change anything else, you'll need to archive it and then create a new one.
Is a customer able to take actions on data in a bot (i.e. cancel specific items in an order)?
Yes, customers can take actions on data in a bot flow if you have set up the APIs that allow them to take that action.
Can I create multiple Custom Objects from one Custom Action call?

Nested objects are not currently supported. This means that if, for example, the API is returning a list of orders as objects - we will first need to pull those orders in to identify the right order - and then, once we have the order ID, we can pull the items related to that order. With this, there would be a User-Order relationship and a User-Item relationship. Learn more about relationship types here.
How do I store the token for Custom Actions?
Tokens are stored as part of header configuration in our database. These values are  encrypted at rest. Find documentation on security at Intercom.
Is there a retry mechanism for Custom Actions
No this is not supported explicitly with Custom Actions. Instead, the triggering is controlled by the workflow to ensure that teammates and customers get timely responses.
Can I branch based on error codes returned from the API i.e 4xx, 5xx?

Reusing API error codes in subsequent bot flow is not currently supported. The bot flow has split paths by successful/unsuccessful Custom Action triggers. However, depending on the API, you could store API responses so that they can be used in subsequent bot workflows for branching. So if the API response JSON has an attribute that has response details like ‚Äústatus‚Äù, you could store that response status as a Conversation CDA and use it in bots for branching.
What authentication methods are available for Custom Actions?

Custom Actions support both fixed and dynamic tokens for authentication. You can set up and manage your authentication tokens that you want to use in the request, which can then be added to the header.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher

content.title: Install and set up Switch
content.description: Learn how to set up Switch and move phone conversations to Messenger.
sections: Using Switch, you can move customers from phone to chat conversations and reduce hold times, offering a better customer experience in a space where your team can handle volume more efficiently.
To set up Switch, navigate to Settings > Switch. Under the ‚ÄúInstallation guide‚Äù you'll find two ways to integrate Switch with your phone system:

Install via Call Forwarding - This is quick to set up, requires no coding or API integration and every phone system supports call forwarding. Install via API - If your phone system has the option to call an HTTP API, you can use this more robust option to pass data from your phone system and create multiple rules or bots in Intercom based on this information.

First, you'll need to request a phone number to forward calls from your existing phone system to Intercom Messenger. Your forwarding phone number will automatically generate when you select ‚ÄúRequest phone number‚Äù.
Note: This number will be a US forwarding number which is not visible to your customers, it's only used in the background for forwarding calls to.

Important: There's no charge to request this number but some phone systems may charge for forwarding a call to an external number, particularly if the number is international. Check with your phone plan and provider.
Call the forwarding number to experience the conversation switch. You will hear the pre-recorded thank you message, receive an SMS and find the conversation created in your Intercom Inbox.
You will need to create an option to forward to your new forwarding number in your IVR editor.
Here's an example of how this looks in Aircall. Your IVR might look a little different, but it will follow a similar process:
Go to your IVR editor and add an IVR option to forward to an external number.
Then copy and paste in the forwarding number you received from Intercom.
Important: You must send the original caller's ID when you forward the call. This is so the SMS can be sent to your Inbox.

Implement Switch as a silent option in your phone system by simply adding the IVR option to forward the call, without adding an audible message to the IVR menu description. This will let your team test the forwarding option in your phone system by dialling your chosen key number to switch to Messenger, but your customers won't hear a prompt to switch.
Once you're happy with the experience, add an audible message to the IVR editor so callers know switching to chat is an option.
Here are a few example scripts you can adapt to your business brand and voice:

"Thank you for calling us. All our agents are busy at the moment. You can remain on hold, or you can switch to our online messenger by pressing 1", or"If you'd like to switch to chat to avoid waiting on hold, please press 2".
You have the option to add a thank you message for opting to switch to the messenger.
Just go to step 4 and upload an mp3. üëá
If you have any questions during the installation process, check out these Switch FAQs for advice.
To integrate Switch via API, select ‚ÄúInstall via API‚Äù. Your Switch API token will be available for you to copy and use when adding an option to your phone system.
Then make an HTTP POST request. You can include any custom variables you'd like in this call following the format below. These will either match existing user CDAs in Intercom or create new CDAs.
Important: When making the request, make sure your customer's phone number is formatted using E.164 standards.

Tip: Pass data collected by your phone system (i.e. name, location, company) to Intercom and create multiple Inbox Rules and/or Custom Bots based on information collected. You can set this up as part of the API call as a key <> value pairing. For example, if the caller pressed 1 to talk to support then switched, you could route based on the fact they already selected 1 on the phone.
Make a call to your API token from your phone system to experience the conversation switch. You will receive an SMS when you switch to chat and find the conversation created in your Intercom Inbox.
Important: The call to the API token must include the original caller's ID. This is so the SMS can be sent to your Intercom Inbox.

Tip: We recommend implementing Switch as a silent option in your phone system first so your team can test the full experience before you set it live. To do this, simply add an option into your phone system without any audible messages.
How do I set it live for customers?
Once you're happy with the experience, add your audible message to introduce the new option for customers to switch to chat, then add your thank you / goodbye message.
Here are a few example scripts for "Switch to chat messages" to help get you started:

"Thank you for calling us. All our agents are busy at the moment. You can remain on hold, or you can switch to our online messenger by pressing 1", or"If you'd like to switch to chat to avoid waiting on hold, please press 2".
Here's an example script for a "Goodbye message" you can customize to fit your brand:
"Thank you for choosing to switch to messaging. We have sent you an SMS with a link to our online messenger. Please click that link to continue. Goodbye for now".
If you have any questions during the installation process, check out these Switch FAQs for advice.

content.title: Automate Switch workflows with Custom Bots and Inbox rules
content.description: Increase your team efficiency further by using Custom Bots and Inbox rules for easy conversation handling.
sections: Improve your team efficiency further by using Custom Bots to target Switch customers specifically, and let Inbox rules automate workflows.
Target your Switch customers specifically by copying the URL under Settings > Switch > Custom Bots on Switch.
Then click ‚ÄúSet up Custom Bots‚Äù and edit or duplicate an existing Custom Bot from new conversations.
In your Custom Bot, go to Rules > Where to send, and add a page rule where ‚ÄúCurrent page URL contains via.intercom.io‚Äù.
You can also use the Switch template when you create ‚ÄúNew Custom Bot‚Äù from Custom Bots > From new conversations as a starting point to specifically target customers that Switch.
Important: When you use a Custom Bot to target customers that Switch, make sure this bot is ordered higher in priority than other bots so that it will trigger.

Note: Custom Bots work with Switched conversations even without targeting them specifically. So if you have Custom Bots that target users or leads, they will appear in the Switch conversation automatically.
Route Switch conversations in the Inbox using rules to ensure they go straight to the right people and place.
Go to Inbox > Automation > Rules and edit an existing rule, or create a new rule. Then add a condition ‚ÄúFrom Phone Switch is true‚Äù to route based on Switch conversations.
This rule works well alongside other existing attributes such as:
Phone number - use ‚ÄòStarts with' and the country code to route to specific country teams.CDAs - to route based on specific attributes (if you used the API installation for Switch).
For example, if you wanted to route all VIP Spanish customers to your VIP Spanish Support team, you could use the following attributes:
Learn more about automating your inbox workflows with Rules here.

content.title: Customize the Switch experience
content.description: Personalize the experience for your customers and decide how switched conversations are identified by your teammates.
sections: Customizing a few settings makes the Switch experience feel more personal. Start by editing the SMS to match your company brand and tone, and allow teammates to acknowledge your existing customers who have switched to Messenger.
Customize the experience for your customers
The SMS that your customers will receive when they press the option to Switch is completely customizable and you can update this across all the languages you have set up to support.
Go to Switch settings > Customize the experience and click on ‚ÄúSwitch SMS‚Äù. Then click inside the message on screen to start editing it.

Note: The SMS to switch the conversation will come from a US number. If your customer's country supports alphanumeric SMS, they will see your business's name when they receive the SMS instead of the phone number.

Important: Your customers will receive either SMS or email notifications about subsequent replies to the conversation if they leave the Messenger. SMS notifications will only be sent if the customer's email address is not known.
Customize the experience for your teammates

By default, Switch is set to create a new lead when a conversation starts. You'll need to opt in if you'd like Switch to automatically identify existing users by their phone number, so your teammates can have all their customer information to hand.
To opt in, go to Switch settings > Identifying existing users and select this option:
When this option is selected, Switch will associate the conversation with existing users in Intercom who have a matching phone number. If no matching phone number exists, a new lead will be created.
Important: Some phone numbers stored in Intercom might have been collected automatically, e.g. via a Bot. You should verify your users' identity before discussing sensitive information.
If you stay opted out, a new lead will be created for every switched conversation.

After switching to the Messenger, your customer will need to send a message for a conversation to be created in the Inbox. Teammates can tell it's a switched conversation by an internal note that says ‚ÄúInbound call from [customer's phone number] switched to chat.‚Äù
Now that the conversation has moved to Messenger, teammates can respond to this conversation the same way they currently use the Inbox.
Note: Switched conversations will act like any other conversation in the Messenger and CSAT will be sent when closed (if turned on in Operator > Task Bots settings).

content.title: Monitor Switch conversations and see reports
content.description: Monitor your Switch usage in detail and find conversation reports.
sections: When you start deflecting calls to the Messenger, you'll want to see some stats to know how well it's working, such as how many switched and how many started a conversation.
View your Switch usage in detail by going to Settings > Switch > Monitor:

Switched means the end user decided to switch from the phone call.Messenger Opened means the end user clicked the link in the SMS to open the Messenger.Conversation Started means the end user sent a message in the Messenger.
Note: If you click on ‚Äú2 conversations started‚Äù you'll see a list with those conversations as shown below:
Next to each switched call, you'll be able to see if a conversation started.
Click on the conversation button to see a list of all conversations that started via Switch. The selected conversation will open first.
Teammates can report on Switched conversations by filtering or breaking down by channel > Phone Switch. This is accessible in all Customer Support reports, CSV exports and Custom reports.

content.author:
Written by  Beth-Ann Sher
 Updated over a week ago
content.title: Switch FAQs
content.description: Learn more about Switch with these answers and tips.
sections: Here are some answers to common questions you may have during the Switch setup and installation‚Ä¶
Does Switch work with my phone system?
Yes! Switch works with all phone systems. But not all phone systems can use the API method of installation so you may need to use the call forwarding method.
What's the best way to install?

There are two ways two set up Switch - via call forwarding and API. Many of our customers use call forwarding to set up Switch as it's simple and compatible with all phone systems. The API offers more control and customization for handling call data, but isn't compatible with some phone systems such as Aircall, Zendesk, and TalkDesk.
In short, if you want a straightforward setup, call forwarding is a great option. But if you want a more robust option, find out if your phone system supports API and try this installation.
Does it work outside of the US?
Yes, Switch will work almost anywhere in the world, except New Zealand and Saudi Arabia (due to local SMS laws).
Note: Since we currently only provide US forwarding numbers, if you're not based in the US, some phone systems may charge you for international call forwarding.
How does Switch handle users and leads?

By default, Switch creates a new lead when a conversation starts. You can change this in Switch settings. If you opt to identify existing users, Switch will associate the conversation with existing users in Intercom who have a matching phone number. If no matching phone number exists, a new lead will be created. And if two users with the same number already exist, the conversation will be attached to the user who was seen last.
When does Switch try to merge user and lead profiles?
Switch only tries to merge profiles when the conversation first comes in. If there is no phone number match at this stage, nothing will merge.
How will I be charged for using Switch?

Switch is charged based on how many calls you deflect with it each month. A deflected call is counted when the user selects the option to switch on the phone call. You will be charged even if the end user never sends a message in the messenger. The pricing model is tiered based on your usage, with the price points found here.
How can I see how many calls are deflected?

You can easily see how many calls you've deflected by filtering the Conversations report by ‚ÄúPhone switch‚Äù. You can also keep tabs on all your Switch usage through the ‚ÄúMonitor‚Äù tab in Switch settings. Find out more about reporting here.
This is the message you add to your IVR which lets your customers know they can switch to chat in the Messenger. Here are a few example scripts you can adapt to your business:

"Thank you for calling us. All our agents are busy at the moment. You can remain on hold, or you can switch to our online messenger by pressing 1", or"If you'd like to switch to chat to avoid waiting on hold, please press 2".
What happens if someone calls in from a landline?

Switch will check to see if the phone number can receive an SMS. If not, it will prompt the caller to put in their mobile number so it can send an SMS to them. Canada is the only country from which we cannot detect if the phone number is a landline or a mobile phone.

Note: We cannot send SMS or prompt the caller for their mobile number in the case of private numbers or numbers starting with 0800 (non-geographic toll-free). In these cases we recommend setting up a conditional block in your phone system and not offer Switch as an option if the number is private or starts with 0800.
Does the Switch SMS support localization?
Yes, the SMS sent to your customers from Switch is completely customizable across all the languages you have set up to support.
Read through our installation and setup guide for your chosen installation method.

content.title: Your Intercom reports explained
content.description: Use Intercom's reports to measure and understand your Lead generation, Customer engagement, and Customer Support.
sections: Intercom's reports offer a breakdown of everything important to your business.

Whether you use Intercom for Convert, Support, or Engage. This article breaks down all the available reports, and the information you'll find in each. Click the links below to jump to a specific section:
Overview reportLead generation reportsCustomer engagement ‚Äî Messages reportCustomer support reports
This report gives a high level overview of what's going on in your Intercom workspace:

People ‚Äî See your new users and leads and how they've interacted with your team.Conversations ‚Äî See new inbound messages & replies to your outbound content.Performance ‚Äî Monitor how quickly your team respond, and how satisfied your customers are.Self-service Support ‚Äî Find the questions that Resolution Bot resolves most often, and your top articles.
See your Overview report here, or learn more about the metrics in this article.
The Leads report gives a clear look at how your team is generating new leads with Intercom. You'll see:

New leads generated through the Messenger.Your team's first response time to leads.Which messages are bringing in the most new leads.How many leads have been created in Salesforce from Intercom's Salesforce app.
See your Leads report here, or learn more about the metrics in this article.
The Sales report is most useful with Intercom's Salesforce app and shows you:

Meetings booked through Intercom.Time to close opportunities.Revenue influenced by Intercom (Opportunities, Pipeline & Closed won).Deals influenced by Intercom.Conversions by message and page.Teammate's sales performance.
See your Sales report here, or learn more about the metrics in this article.
The Custom Bots report offers insight into the impact that Custom Bots have on your lead generation efforts. You'll find:

An engagement summary (Bots Sent, Engaged with & Completed).Emails collected.Leads created in Salesforce.Leads disqualified.Meetings booked.Conversations assigned to your team.The busiest periods for your Custom Bots.
See your Custom Bots report here, or learn more about the metrics in this article.
The Customer Engagement report lets you see how your ongoing messages are performing, whether your messages are sending as expected and if any users have received too many messages.
Messages sent over time.Message volume by user.Message performance.You can also export your message statistics as a CSV. üëå
See your Customer Engagement report here, or learn more about the metrics in this article.
This report gives you insight into your team's workload, the issues your customers are facing and the state of your inboxes.
With dynamic filters, you can see the following data, organized by team, topic, channel and more:
New conversations (inbound, and in reply to messages or bots).Conversations replied to and individual replies sent.Closed, open & snoozed conversations.Busiest periods for new conversations.
Note: The data in this report used to be on two separate reports; New Conversations and Performance > Volume.
See your Conversations report here, or learn more about the metrics in this article.
This report shows you how conversations are assigned to your teams, how quickly they respond and offers an in-depth look at how your individual teammates are performing.
Nuanced filtering lets you break down team and teammate data in whichever way suits you best. You'll find:
Conversations assigned by team.First reply time by team.
Conversations, assigned, replied to & closed.Their response times, time to close, notes and mentions.CSAT ratings from customers.
See your Team performance report here, or learn more about the metrics in this article.

This report shows you all conversation ratings and remarks from customers, so you can celebrate your high performers, and help those who might need some coaching. Advanced filtering enables you to see how your team performs on different topics or conversation types.
See your Customer satisfaction report here, or learn more about the metrics in this article.
This report offers a quick overview, and a more in-depth look at your team's response times and time to close conversations. Responsiveness is broken down by channel, day and hour.
See your Responsiveness report here, or learn more about the metrics in this article.
This report lets you see how effectively your support team handles conversations over time. It highlights:
Conversations replied to.Closed conversations on first contact.Teammate replies to close a conversation.Reassignments.Time to first assignment.Time from first assignment to close.
See your Effectiveness report here, or learn more about the metrics in this article.
This report presents the total number of tagged conversations over time, and the number of conversations with specific tags. You'll get an overview of any trends, and can easily export the report.
See your Conversation tags report here, or learn more about the metrics in this article.
This report gives you insight into where your team is meeting or missing your SLA targets.
Periods where targets are hit or missed.Performance against each target over time.Success rate for meeting customer expectations.
See your SLAs report here, or learn more about the metrics in this article.
This report sheds light on how your help content is performing, so that you can improve the self-serve support experience for your customers. It shows:
A summary of article views.Search terms with no results.Which articles start conversations and get reactions.
See your Articles report here, or learn more about the metrics in this article.
This report shows you the impact Resolution Bot has on your business. You can measure:
Conversations resolved immediately.Customer and teammate hours saved.Conversation coverage.Resolution rate.
See your Resolution Bot report here, or learn more about the metrics in this article.
This report shows an overview of how effective your Custom Bots are, and can be filtered down to the individual bot level. You'll find:
An engagement summary (Bots Sent, Engaged with & Completed).Conversations assigned to your team.The busiest periods for your Custom Bots.
Note: To report on Custom Bot's impact on lead generation, like Emails collected, Leads qualified & Meetings booked, see the lead generation report instead.
See your Custom Bots report here, or learn more about the metrics in this article.
This report shows an overview of your team's ticket handling, and can be filtered down to individual ticket types, on a team or teammate level. You'll find:

Median time to resolveMedian time in submittedMedian time in progressMedian time in waiting for customerMedian time to resolve by dateMedian time to resolve by teamMedian time to resolve by teammateNew ticketsResolved ticketsNew vs resolved tickets by weekTicket volume by assigned teamTicket volume by assigned teammate
See your Tickets report here, or learn more about the metrics in this article.
If you require a more detailed breakdown of your conversation data, or would like to archive it for record keeping purposes, you can also export a CSV of your conversations in a given date range.
Export your conversation data now, or find out more about what's included in this article.
